Entry.1:
At Beutin

Well I have had a very good time today under the prevailing circumstances.

The weather has been very cold`s late, but today the Clerk seems to have made some resolutions, for the New Year, and has certainly given us a glorious day.

I went for a long walk this morning to Beutin, a la Coloterie, a village ten kilos off.

My billet pals two, being Scotchmen have celebrated the festive day rather well.

Our lunch today was cooked by the Madame who owns our billet, and consisted of fowls and potatoes roasted, washed down by coffee
Entry.2:
At Beutin

Last night – the weather changed bringing a transformation of scenery to meet our awakening eye. Beautiful white snow was draped on every natural object, erasing here an ugly mark and softening the dull aspect of our billet.

The morning sun`s radiance however soon melted the work of the Clerk, and dirtied the footpaths and roads. We worked the usual routine today, and I had a game of footer during the afternoon. Smith and James were very "sore" this morning.
Entry.3:
At Beutin

Worked during morning in accordance with our Routine which is Reveille, 7.15. Stables 7.30, Breakfast 8, Parade at Gun Park, 9.30am and detailed for duties. Stables 11am. Dinner 12.30 pm. Stables 4 pm. Dismiss 4.30 pm.

There has been a very severe frost and the result has left us with ice bound roads. Mac, proceeded to Boulogne to see his Sister who is nursing in the 29th General.

Soccer team had a victory, 2 to nil . Numerous members of W.A.A.C. watched the game in the company of the fellows of our battery.
Entry.4:
At Beutin

I have to report my first visit to the M.O. today. For the past few days my old wisdom tooth has been having a great time, and I have not had too much sleep. I departed to the dentist via the M.O. to have the cause of the trouble removed. After riding 40 kilos there and home I had the satisfaction of knowing that tomorrow will see the end of my trouble.

Mac has not yet returned from B. our Rough team played today and won . Very heavy frost. Roads like glass.
Entry.5:
At Beutin

Repeated yesterday`s operation and ride, had my tooth pulled by a very capable Staff Sergt in the dental corps attached to A.A.M.C. 

The frost again hardened the roads, and they are indeed in a very treacherous state for uncogged horses. Our little village is still our home; and the Estaminet an rendezvous. 

He the boys gather to played billiards, sit by the fire, and drink coffee, or vin Rouge. Both excellent drinks on cold days.
Entry.6:
At Beitin

Received a considerable amount of mail from Australia, via friend Broome. also two magazines and a pair of gloves from "Mum"- my Cornish friend.

Ah! tis indeed a pleasure to receive letters from home and perhaps they make me just a little homesick – at times.

Received several "snaps" from Les Fuller, and a fairly long letter from Roy who seems to be getting better.
Entry.7:
At Beutin

Received more mail from Australia via "Savernake". These letters were long cheerily written epistles, "Savernake" also writes some very long letters. Answered all my mail during the afternoon. Mac returned from Bolougne. Weather very cold, with bleak winds.

Went with James to Divere Cinema at Attin, 2 kilos away, very good show. Met Dick and Wattie there.
Entry.8:
At Beutin – France

A heavy blizzard commencing at 6.30 am and ceasing at 7 am placed 10" of snow over everything. Drifts in places were 5 to 6 feet deep.

Smith and Thompson`s leave passes – for Paris via Etaples, in high glee.

Went in evening to rendezvous and played cards. Wrote to Roy and Eve.
Entry.9:
At Beutin

Heavy fall of snow, weather very cold and bleak.

Carried out usual routine during morning

Our battery played 55th and won easily – Australia rules

Relieved Gun on Runner work and did a few trips to Bdge Headqrs, at Attin
Entry.10:
Thursday 10

At Beutin

Dick and Wattie to Montreuil, to repair magneto. Report having had a good time.

Sir Douglas Haig`s Hdqrs at above town, 6 kilos from here.

Plenty of "Waccs" in village close by, numbers of fellows have made their acquaintances and pay frequent visits to their camp at La Cotolierie

Went for the Dr. at 9.30pm one of the pretty bad. Rode some 15 kilos before I found him.
Entry.11:
At Beutin 

Have been battery runner today, relieving Gunn who is off to Bolougne. 

Plenty of despatches. Weather fine, but very cold.

Played 10th A.A.S.C. and won by 55-23

James on Stable Picquet. Weather changed to rain and wind at 6 pm. Wrote to Roy.
Entry.12:
At Beutin

Still on Battery Runner, but have not been so busy today.

Weather cold and wet, would rather be in by the fire than out. 

We played 49th battery football and beat them badly, by 35-13. Boys are all jubilant, as this victory puts us at the head of our class.
Entry.13:
At Beutin

Gun returned, back at stables. Marched to Church Parade. Divisional sports decided at Longvillers Battery one Tug-o-War, Broad Jumps, 400 yard championships , and Corbett was beaten by an inch in the Sheffield.

The weathr throughout was rotten, - raining hard, and making everything sloppy. 

Received a letter from smith who is in Paris. He seems to be having a pretty decent time.
Entry.14:
At Beutin

Paid forty francs today by Redmond, in the Local Estaminet Du Gare, the old Madame is rubbing her hands and waiting till six pm when she will gather numerous francs in return for beer and etc.

James was just a little "oiled" not too bad. 

Weather cold but fine. Went to rendezvous and played cards in the evening.
Entry.15:
At Beutin

Usually daily routine .

Weather fine.

Played 53rd Bty a game of Rugby during afternoon result draw 5-5

I went along to Etaples with Dick then to Paris Plage. The latter is in Peace Time a pleasure resort and is indeed a pretty little place.

There are quite a number of W.A.A.C.s camped at the former place.

Etaples is a peace time big fishing centre, and possesses a very large square, not to mention an electric tram service to Paris Plage.
Entry.16:
At Beutin

Went out for lamp practice this morning i/c of Bdr Palmer.

A very pleasant day, not too much snow, or frost. Had a letter from old Len Clements, who is in Blighty. He is on furlough and is having the usual – furlough time. 

Received further news of Roys wounds. He is progressing favourably, and walks with the aid of a crutch. 

Old Bill Brom, wrote some very nice letters which I answered.
Entry.17:
At Beutin

I am feeling rather blue today for I have been thinking about home; however we must not allow such beautiful thoughts to hinder our minds and spirits.

Went in company with the tall James, to the cinema, and enjoyed the programme – fully. Five large and long pictures.

Old Dick looks pretty fit.

Weather fine and warmer than usual.
Entry.18:
At Beutin

Heavy fall of snow during the night.

Smith and Thompson arrived home at 5 am from Paris and slept until 5 pm.

On Battery Orderly today . and in spare time wrote "Sounds of the Night " 

Bomdr Bennet went to Hdqs and Dr Fitzpatrick took his place in the office.

Had several long runs during the night.
Entry.19:
At Beutin

Weather fine. Usual Sig work. Smithy still "out", Thompson not much better.

On Battery Runner.

An uneventful day.
Entry.20:
At Beutin

Macully left for Blighty on leave, Macaffery and Meredith went to report as instructors at R.B.A.A.

Weather very fine.

Big parade on tomorrow general inspection.

Very busy polishing up limbers, harness and etc.

Weather beautiful.

Received a small parcel of socks from Mother and some papers from Blighty and magazines.
Entry.21:
At Beutin

Weather wet and plenty of it. No parade as expected slept all day and played billiards in the evening against Smith and James. They beat me by four, I shall have to handicap them next time we play.
Entry.22:
At Beutin

Grand parade and march past at Attin. Inspection by Generals, Brown and Hobbs.

I was mounted today on a very famous charger, named by some "wag" "Semaphore".

After the inspection Hobbs made a little speech. But we heard very little indeed. I believe we are moving shortly.
Entry.23:
At Beutin

Cleaning and polishing up our phones for the road and line.

Smith and I packed two panniers this morning. Thompson went into Etaples to purchase a few necessities.

Bought some excellent bread at our canteen, 1½ lb loaf.
Entry.24:
At Beutin

A practically uneventful day, weather mild and fine.

Same routine of work. Went to Cinema in the evening with James and Macarron. Programme a very good one.
Entry.25:
At Beutin

I must report on this village. Beutin Pas De Calais, to use the full title, is a small village 6 kilos East of Etaples. The village public buildings are four Estaminets, one church, and the Railway Station. There is a school, a bureax de postes, and the Gendarme National`s residence. There is no other place of mention save the farmhouses which are typical to the other farms.

Usual routine, and game of billiards. Today I won for a change.
Entry.26:
At Beutin

Today has brought a stranger to our village, so the gossips tongues report. The stranger is a fair Mmslle, and has come from Samor, to reside temporarily in this quiet village.

I can see the old villagers tongues wagging in the "tap room" of the Estaminet tonight.

Thompson reports fair progress, also Jamies.

Weather beautiful
Entry.27:
At Beutin

Today has been a glorious day, I went for a walk this morning along a sunlit track bordered by trees on one side and hedges and a stream on the other.

The morning air was frosty and sparkling. I came to an old log straddled across a tree. Here I sat and wrote a long letter home.

We are being paid in all probability tomorrow.
Entry.28:
At Beutin

Owing to some mess up in the acquittance rolls we did not draw our money as expected.

Weather very fine.

Preparing for the road. 

I am once again Battery Runner.

Football team played a match at Paris Plage but were beaten.

Sgt Henderson arrived back and I is charge of "F" sub.
Entry.29:
At Beutin

Paid forty francs at 9.30 am.

Inspection of gas masks at 11 am.

Cleaned the leatherwork of my saddle before lunch, and the steel portion after I had finished lunch.

Thompson rode to Etaples on business for Smithy.

Cinema left Attin. For Dranoutie, I suppose Dick has gone with it.
Entry.30:
At Beutin

Weather fine, a little frost, roads fairly good "Pull out" tomorrow morning so rumor says, at 2.30 am .

Billeting party to leave at dawn.

Spent a few hours on my horse and harness. Cleaned all the old straw out of the billet and made the place a little cleaner.
Entry.31:
On the road

I awoke at 1 am to see old Dick standing over me and enquiring as to where he was to sleep.

Reveille was at 3.30 am today.

We have not come so very far about 25 kilos.

Went for a walk this evening with Jamie and scraped a feed of eggs and bread.
Entry.32:
On the road

Our reveille was at 4.30am today and we pulled into our billets at 4 pm.

The 53rd, 54th, and 55th Batteries are all billeted in the village 

Walked to Lumbres with Jamie and Smithy and had a decent feed of eggs and chips.

Weather fairly good spent an hour on my harness and horse.
Entry.33:
On the road

Reveille at 5.30 am very cold but fine

Passed through St Omer and Wizernes at a fairly early hour

Arrived at our billets a big shed, at 4 pm.

Watered and fed. Short speech by Major congratulating Bty on their smart turn out.

Went into Staples with Jamie, Smith or orderly Sgt. Had a feed of eggs and chips, also some fun in an Estaminet.

Lost ourselves coming home.
Entry.34:
On the road

Reveille at 6.30 am no parade until Boot and Saddle.

Left at 11am. passed through Hazebrouck at 12.30

Arrived at billets, three kilos from Bailleul, at 5.30pm

Am feeling in very high spirits, received letter from Mrs. Adam.

Warned off as horseholder for party going to the guns tomorrow morning

Had a feed of eggs and chips at a little Estaminet facing the billet.
Entry.35:
On the road

Left billet at 9.30 for the Guns. Smithy, Adey, Cody and Garford. Jamie and I as horseholders. Arrived after a tour through Bailleul and Neuve Eglise, at old Battery position, near Messines. Returned to Battery`s billets and had lunch en route. Felt pretty tired so retired at an early hour.

Weather very cold and damp
Entry.36:
On the road – and Messines. Left our billets at 8.30am and arrived at Daylight Corner via Dranoutie and Bailleul at 12.30pm.

Warned to leave for guns immediately on arrival. Packed my kit and went up with gun and Kempe .

Arrived at S.O.S. gun at 2 pm and at pill box at 5 pm.

Took up the 10 till 12 watch.

Weather wet

Have a fine dug-out almost 5.9 proof.
Entry.37:
Messines

Weather fine and clear

Had a look around the vicinity and went across to Anti Tank position and saw Gunn and Russell.

Garford on O.P.

Received small amount of mail.

Had the 10 to 12 watch.

Played cards until ten
Entry.38:
Messines

Weather drizzly with a little wind

Dugout making plenty of water

Had another look around the "possie"

Mills on O.P. Walker on liason

Boys feeling pretty happy good issue of rum tonight 

Smithy still a teetotaller
Entry.39:
Messines

There is a scene of desolation round these parts; on our left and in front of the old pill box, is a mass of ruined houses once a small village. It is known as Guy Farm

On clear days one can see old Fritzies villages, Comines. And Werweick, as marked by a cluster of steeples and church spires.

Weather unsettled

Was on 12 to 2 last night.
Entry.40:
Messines

Weather very windy and dull. Took a turn at O.P.

Kelly and Jones observing officers

No. 3 gun did a good piece of shooting scoring four consecutive hits on a tree.

Was on 2 to 4 last night.

Dugout leaking somewhere.
Entry.41:
Messines 

Spent a very quiet day mostly on the phone. Fritz put a few cinq.neuf over.

Weather very unsettled. Hear there is a raid coming off tonight. Our guns were cutting wire this afternoon. 

Was on 4 to 6 this morning. Went down to canteen and heard the 15th were at Spy Farm, and the 8th were at Daylight Corner.
Entry.42:
Messines

Raid last night on Fritz`s strong post. Captured 25 Fritzies. Casual. 8 killed and 15 wounded. Some fellows of the 31st Batt took part. We supported with the Barrage.

Walked across to Lamp Post Corner to see Gun, and brought back water.

Da Costa arrived at S.O.S. gun. I am for O.P. tomorrow. Mills on laison. Alby on F.O.O.today. 

Weather unsettled
Entry.43:
Messines

On F.O.P, today with Spence and Jones. Spence remained with me till 4.30 pm. Fritz shell 54 Battalion`s line and Rifle Farm to the extent of 180, 5.9. 

A good chap Spence who is being spoiled by "booze".

Weather unsettled and visibility at times – good. 

I have found a dog, a "foxic" who is a terror on rats. He has been all day with me at F.O.P.

Johns has taken up his abode of love in our domicile.
Entry.44:
Messines

Spent last night at l`aison with Mackenson a very decent fellow. I`m afraid he was not impressed with my manners. He heard me address an officer in 29th Battal as Jim. I remained in ignorance of "Jims" identity until closer observation revealed the fact that Jim was a major.

Went to new O.P. with Gun as guide and brought back water.

Pioneers planted a machine gun near our dugout. Precaution against hostile aircraft 

Weather wet.
Entry.45:
Messines

Made two trips to F.O.O. today, gee but it’s a long step.

Made enquiries about E.G.F. and find he is at Spy Farm

Weather has been very unsettled.

Received a wire that Fritz was massing at Lake Farm . 

Our Bty put 20 rounds in. 

Had the 2 to 4 this morning.

Feeling fairly tired after so much travelling today, so I must drink my run and pop into bed.
Entry.46:
Messines

Had the 4 to 6 shift on the phone and this morning.

Walked to Spy Farm and met old Les Fuller and Duncan.

Had tea with Les and proceeded on to Daylight Corner, saw Thompson and James. Had a pow pow. Believe that Ike Steinthal is in the 10th Field Coy, also some of the others.

Weather wet, altho a little better today.

Fritz shelled for a couple of hours. Garford and Mills on L`aison.
Entry.47:
Messines

Went to F.O.O.with Garfott with Mackensen`s lunch. Battery fired a few rounds at a Fritzer plane. Great deal of aeriel activity throughout the day and night.

Weather beautiful, a little frosty, shell holes covered with ice.

Visibility very good.

Had a rather disastrous evening at cards.

Wrote to Doug Fraser and Ike Steinthal.

Had the 10 to 12 watch last night.
Entry.48:
Messines

Fritz`s planes have been very active – throughout the day. One was brought down on our right. One of ours was was brought down in flames, the wing following the body in descent.

Crossed one of our howitzers fire.

Went on L`aison with Mr Kerr, to left Batt. 

Les paid me a visit, and remained here for tea.

Weather glorious but a little frosty. Smithy getting quite well again, and looks much brighter.
Entry.49:
Messines

Well our friend the Bosche was giving a fine exhibition of daring flying to-day. Went down to canteen and "Pip" having some lunch in Gunn`s company.

Weather frosty and clear, very piercing wind from S.E. Garfoot out on O.P. all day. Chas Adey, on a visit to W.Lines.

Had a shot at old Fritz with the Lewis gun. 

Went on duty at 12 to 2am during the night.
Entry.50:
Messines

Left "Pill box" at 6 am, with Mr Kerr, for Forward Observation Post, via Bob trench.

There was a cold hard surface on the ground, and a knife edged wind.

I had to fall in a shell hole, and make myself a iceberg until the sun thawed me out.

At midday we did our shoot,Baab Farm and Pill ditto.

At 9 pm, we had a stunt and supported our infantry in a raid.

Fritz had his S.O.S. up very quickly

Approached re leave to Australia.
Entry.51:
Messines

Fritz shelled in our direction from 7 am to 11.15 – no damage done.

Weather wet and fairly cold

Went down to O.P. with Jone`s lunch and had a little pow pow pow with Gun.

Wrote an informal applic. for leave to Australia and handed same to Bty Clerk.

Visibility purely rotten, so the guns did very little shooting. Barrage put up for raiding partly last night. 

Did the 2 to 4 shift.
Entry.52:
Messines

Unfortunately my pen has assumed legs and disappeared to my deep regret.

I had the 2 to 4 shift this morning, whilst Garford was L`aison tonight. I`m next on tap for L`aison . 

Fritz put one or two on the road in front of Battery and blew up a portion of the railway line to Bty position with a nice 8" shell.

Weather fine. Battery got on to a dozen or more Fritzs `s at work on wire, result 2 casualties, also gave Baab Farm, Sq Farm and Pill Farm a few wallops.
Entry.53:
Messines

Walked down to F.O.O. and "took" Jones dinner. Jones is going to another Battery.

Had a great feed last night and tonight. I was chef and dished up, Soup-a la Oxe-des Ra, Turnips, Mashed –a la Bully Beef, and Xmas Pudding and choice almond flavoured custard. Had the 10-12 and 6-8, so had my share of "Yakker".

Fritz very quiet.

Wrote to London for Blue,bhewars
Entry.54:
Messines

Spent the day in usual duties, and had some visual work in morning.

Weather dull.

On L`aison with Kerr and listened in at 59th Batt. wireless receiver, to Kiel Wireless Station and also a couple of Dutch Stations at Zeebrugge.

Camped with Bombers and found them good chaps.

Day a very quiet one had a couple of shots with 3 star rifles at an old turnip.
Entry.55:
Messines

Had a fairly quiet day, and visited Gunn, and Da Costa at Anti Tank position.

Garfott on F.O.O. my turn tomorrow.

Fritz shelled the Corner Dump like hell for an hour

Received letters from Mrs Ladd, M, Mother and Uncle Graham the former via Mr 

Weather dull, but with clear patches. Great aeriel activity.

Won five francs form Russell. Laurence returned form Leave.
Entry.56:
Messines

Rained like the very deuce this morning. Left home at 6 am, with Kerr for F.O.P.

Spent a rather chilly forenoon and registered Baab Farm

In afternoon, whilst registering Code F, saw a Fritz arise like a spirit under the persistence of an 18 pounder H.E.

Arrived home, 6.15 pm. Glorious moonlight night .

Fritz dropped a few eggs on supports.

Received letters from Doug H, and Mother
Entry.57:
Messines

Gee but it has been cold today. I did old Garfortt`s shift for him so therefore slept all day today. Waking only for meals. Wrote several letters.

Executed the 8 to 12 pm midnight. Charlie Adey well stung.

A bit of a stunt on at 7.15 pm a small barrage.

Witnessed a perfect sunrise this morning dressed in a shirt and top boots. 

Tom Codey waiting for leave pass to arrive.
Entry.58:
Messines

Had a very quiet morning. Strolled down to Daylight Corner and "bagged" a horse. Rode to Dranoutre to Baths. Had a good bath and got a clean change of clothes. Had lunch at Waggon lInes. "Tommo" pretty well screwed.

Albert and Charlie were my companions during the visit. Saw Jamie, cleaning limbers. Fritz shelled the house at F.O.P. and the occupants drifted off. 

Garfoot on L`aison
Entry.59:
Messines

Walked across to Tank –pos and spent day with Gun. Received a quantity of mail including the remains of a parcel passed through customs.

Weather delightful. Great scare here, O.P. manned at 4

am. Fritz had a stunt

near Ypres.- no results to hand yet. Fritz bracketed our

position 

with.5.9, and two 8 inch. He also bracketed the 53rd Bty.

He also executed quite a considerable amount of

registering on the road and 

Wewique. 1 Fritz plane down
Entry.60:
Messines

Spent a fairly quiet day and registered for Warneton help in S.O.S. through 5 boards.

Weather, snow and sleet during morning, very cold in afternoon.

Went to L`aison with Kerr at 7 pm turned in at 8 pm S.O.S. went up from Orange Trench, at 20 to 10 pm. Guns were all in action 5 sec later.

Fritz put his barrage down on supports. Smashed up the wires badly .

Fritz came a "cropper" and did not reach our wire.

Ceased fire at 11 pm.
Entry.61:
Messines

Received letter from Geo Lang--- who is in hospital in Blighty.

Fritz strafed us with H.V.s all the morning. To be sure I had ze vind up. He dropped one in front of our Pill Box, scattering same with sand.

Journeyed to P.gun for compass snowed and sleeted all the afternoon – bitterly cold.

Garfoot trotted down to H.Q.for the pigeons, and we now have deux pigeons for company.

Had a long letter from Roy.
Entry.62:
Messines

During the gale, in early hours of the morning, one of our wires went. Found it necessary to repair same toutes suite. Left at 4.20 pm arrived back at 6.30 am. A great quantity of snow fell during the night.

Went to Bdge Hdqs for pigeons and returned with two birds. – blue checkers, which are used in carrying work when lines go.

Stunts in all sectors last night at 11.15pm., beautiful display of fireworks. Our battery was in the Barrage. Work. Have not yet heard how things progressed.
Entry.63:
Messines

Had a big stunt at 2 am. this morning. Weather wet. Spent the usual day. Am for O.P. tomorrow. Received Customs memo.

At 12.5 midnight, we were barraging for a raid. Still raining. 

Roussell out at O.P. Walker went for pigeons. Loaned A.G. 151.

Formed a picture Gallery in dugout.

Rumoured that Eggs-a-cook stunt of 2nd was a failure that’s why they 

"hopped over" at midnight.
Entry.64:
Messines

Had an S.O.S. call at 2.7 am. Fritz put his barrage down for a fairly long stretch of time.

Had the
Entry.65:
and left for F.O.P. at 6.30 with Mr Kerr.

Weather dull, with icy winds from W.S.W.

Spent a chilly morning.

Mr May the news officer from D.A.C.arrived out at O.P. with Charlie.

Kerr although looking very seedy, registered the Lens lines Code F.M. and Square FM for the Officers benefit.

Let the carrier pigeons go at 5 to 4.

March 1918

Messines

Really, a fairly busy day, aeriel activity having first place, and artillery next. Seemed as if Fritz was preparing for a little stunt – poor old Fritz what a shock he will get. 

Knipe – alias Lightning arrived at P-t with Percy Grayling to relieve Garfott, yesterday. 

Big fatigue party working about the line, they seem pretty busy. Shells fell in several co-ordinated spots fairly handy, one did a little damage. Paid Geo Baker and Mick a visit during evening.
Entry.66:
Messines

Spent a fairly quiet day at P., with Smithy. Went along for birds.

Marcolm Mills, drifted to Blighty for a spell and also to obtain his transfer to Dental Corps.

Have not received any letters for some time. Drifted to L`aison with Mr Mason at 6.10 pm.

Fritz tried at raid around Menin Road. 2 Battalions of 31st Prussian Div, went over. 

Beautifully clear day. Tower at Wewique brought down by 15" How, also a Bosche plane.
Entry.67:
March 1918

Messines

C.R.A. and col paid a visit to Bty position, and inspected our pit.

Fritz threw a few about, and sent a few waves of chlorine down about the Kemmel end of the line. Met Donnellan, Morell and a few more of the boys in the 30th on the duckboards.

Weather beautiful.

Met Dick Pernell, at P.gun, believe he is going to Blighty on tour with 5th Aus Div concert party. He looks jolly well. Had a decent feed at Pip with Reuss, Ivan, and Ken Brown and Corp Moncur from 51st came across on a visit.
Entry.68:
Messines

Spent the morning from 4 to 6 am on watch and from that hour until noon in bed. Fritz shelled O.P. and front line fairly heavily all day.

Smith nearly sniped with a 4.2 H.V. whilst enroute to the line.

Paid a visit to Pip`s crowd and had a fairly decent time.

9.45 pm Fritz doing a fair amount of shelling on dump.

11 pm.Clocks advanced 1 hour. Fritz still having a shoot. And is expected to come over in lump tonight.
Entry.69:
Messines

Had a holiday today, and spent the forenoon in sleep, eventually drifting down to the W.L. and camp of the 30th Infantry Batt, at Wulverchem.

Met Donellan, Richards Bob Court, and Sid Morell. 

Weather clear and warm.

Fritz distributed some rather good iron rations during day.

Am down for Forward Observation Post tomorrow with Mr. Kerr.

10.30pm. Fritz shelling pretty consistently, Hdqs right Batt and just a few on the left.
Entry.70:
Messines

Spent a very interesting day with Mr.Kerr, at Forward O.P. came under fairly heavy shell fire during the morning. In the afternoon we went forward for three fifty yards, to obtain better observation. Major just missed being sniped.

Weather warm, and very pleasant. When coming in we passed 53rd Officer and two Spooks en route to the line to partake in the big raid by 57th, 58th, and 59th.

10.32 pm Big stunt commenced. Plenty of fireworks, from Fritz`s way. 

Very clear night.

Raiding party home at 11.52 pm. raid successful. 15 prisoners.
Entry.71:
Messines

Weather beautiful, warm fine and clear.

Spent forenoon at pit, and proceeded with Russell and Costa down to Kemmel.

Met Dick Pennell at 5.10 pm. and had the privilege of seeing a very good show. Kookaburras. Hobbs and his staff were present.

During the afternoon a German Observation balloon was brought down at Kemmel.

I received a souvenier portion from Watson.

Anti-tank spooks went forward to O.P. an we had to rush up home again to go forward.
Entry.72:
Messines

Another glorious day, beautiful sunny and warm day.

After hurrying home last night we did not have to go forward. A 15 pounder was taken up as advanced A.T. gun.

Procceded to L`aison with Mr Kerr at 6.30 pm.

Raid timed to come off at 3.20.am tomorrow morning.

Weather at 6.30 pm, considerably colder and Meteor figures show rain is about.

No.6 came over to Bty. Positon at 6 am. also the spooks with exception of Ken Gunn who has gone forward with A.T. gun
Entry.73:
Messines

Went down forward, with Charlie Adey, and had a little while with Ken Gunn.

By appearance of country around about the F.O.O. Fritz has been very busy with 4.2" and whizz bangs.

Weather wet and indeed very sloppy.

.60 hopped the bags at 3.20am. raid very successful. 4 prisoners and 2 casualties.

Came home from L`aison with Kerr, at 9.30 am. after a very quite night.

Things in general fairly quiet.
Entry.74:
Messines

Another fairly quiet day. Weather splendid, very little hostile artillery.

Hun got 1 target from 40 rds of 5.9 down the 51 way. Battery did an aeroplane shoot. 

Mr Mays parti to the A.T.P. 6.35pm.Fritz sent a few decent ones across.

Received balance of articles from customs department.

Knipe went back to W. Lines. 

Finished my Australia, and engrave same with penknife.

Received paper form Stella.

11.30 pm Fritz shelling fairly regularly.
Entry.75:
Messines

2 am. Fritz still dropping them on road.

Another glorious day, weather simply beautiful. Received letters from Roy, Mum, Miss Carmichael and "Toots L." 

Paid by Redmond at 5 pm. Went across to 53rd and delivered pigeon book.

To- Rhodes. Had a yarn to him also Tommy Barr.

9.10 pm. Fritz plastered roads and put a few gas shells over, sneezing gas.

Ivan on O.P. all day, came in at 7pm. Russell on l`aison.
Entry.76:
Messines

Went down to F.O.O. at 6.30 am with rations and etc. 

Spent all day until 7 pm at the O.P. Battery doing some good sniping. Some beautiful bursts by M.T.M.

7.15 pm Seven Fritzer planes sailed over our lines but were driven back by A.A.F..

At 10.30 pm Fritz put down a barrage of "Mustard" shells and shelling, and shelling Left Batt fairly solidly all the while for at least half an hour.

A "pigeon" bomb lobbed in a W.C. possie of 32nd Batt, 5 men became casualties.
Entry.77:
Messines

2 am. Fritz throwing them about rather liberally, very few in our direction.

Another glorious day.

Washed all the towels in the dugout.

O.B.W., returned to W.L. Laurence arrived up at position.

Fritz did some good ranging at 53rd and roadway, with H.E.s and 4.2 air bursts.

11pm. Fritz shelled road with gas, and 5.9 H.E.s.

Grayling out at O.P. 

Had a F.P.C. from A.D.S. who imparts information that he is well.

Wrote R.L. and Mum
Entry.78:
Messines

4.30 am. F.O.O. and A.T.P. heavily shelled with gas and HE 

5am Roadway received another pasting with gas and HV

At 6 am it commenced to rain and did not discontinue all day through.

I guided Laurence to O.P. and on my return went to HQ for the pigeons, but came back without any birds owing to the rain.

At midnight Fritz shelled F.O.P. some more, and increased the calibre to 4.2

Received a letter from Roy, he is awfully "bucked" about some good news.
Entry.79:
Messines

2 am Fritz putting a few across the road, very little gas.

Rained throughout the day until 4 pm.

Went down to Regt Battl to see "Wireless"

Cooked the breakfast and was M.O. all day, had a clean up on strength of it.

Pill box leaks on top, caused plenty of amusement and discomfort.

Russell and Adey went out to O.P. the former relieved Gun of his duties.

Charlie Adey went across to L`aison. Not feeling very brilliant
Entry.80:
Messines

4.35 am Fritz is having a great time. For the last quarter of an hour he has pummeled the line and BH. Hdq both, right and left. 2 am. a shell probably an 8" fell on "6" subs hut 9 casualties. Young McCarron died of wounds at 14th C.C.S.

At 7.7 a.m. S.O.S. through Bdge,and cease fire at 7.35 am.

Fritz shelled corduroy, and around 53rd and our positions, fairly constantly throughout the day. Went down to O.P. with Kerr and laid a new line to Spy Farm. Had a few around our residence – small ones
Entry.81:
Messines

Spent the day at F.O.P. Did a shoot during afternoon. Weather fine but misty.

Fritz put down heavy barrage on the Warncton Sector.

News came to hand per Major to the effect that Fritz had recaptured Bulle and Lagnicourt

Had tea and sujpper with some fellows of the Wireless section at right Battaln.

I did L`aison with "Dope"

Uneventful night. Created a record for duckboard trotting.
Entry.82:
Messines

Weather beautiful and warm.

Had a swim in mine crater – small one, quite close to our home.

Smithy trotted into Dranoutie with Laurence. 

Went for a stroll during afternoon with Ken and visited canteen, also wireless Boe`s.

Very little shelling all day ie. From Fritz, our hows and 60s did some splendid work.

We had a little snipe at a few Fritz officers.

All leave cancelled also. All schools – looks like a stunt
Entry.83:
Messines

Arose at 6.30 and prepared breakfast, worked on souveniers until 10 pm.

Another glorious day, Charlie Adey and Gunn went to W.L.

At 12.15 pm orders came across wire that M.G.s had to report home again

At 1.30pm we packed up all our kits in readiness to "Emshee" to another Bty possie near Oostenhaven Wood.

11.45 pm arrived to our destination and took over from some fellows of the 15th Bty .Damn rotten possie with no dugouts.
Entry.84:
Oosterhaven Wood – Hollebeke. Had a rather strenuous night. And early morning.

2am guns very quiet on both sides.

At &am . Fritz put down a barrage of 5.9 on Zero road which is a very close proximity to the camp

Weather fairly cool. Walked across to old Bty position. 

More casualties at W.L. Bob Elyod and his brother both killed. Ardey kolar, both legs off. Charlie Smith severely wonded. Davis, a Blighty, Pat Crowe one leg taken off at knee, Boys were all out grazing when it happened
Entry.85:
Hollebeke. Zero Road

3.30am Fritz shelling at intervals 10 seconds, - road.for the past few days. I have made no mention of a terrific battle in progress down south. The latest news today regarding the crisis is that Fritz is in Albert. Our Divvie is going down at any time now.

Read a circular issued by Sir Doug Haig, in which he appeals to every man to do his utmost in the critical battle of the war.

Weather fairly cool; Charlie Smith died of wounds at 3pm.
Entry.86:
Hollebeke Zero road. 

6am. Weather very dull and cold, 

Very quiet in this sector, News came through that Fritz was in Albert and had very severe losses in getting there.

Ardey Kolar died of wounds at
Entry.87:
F.A. Kemmel at midday.

Packed up kit and four of us were relieved by the 36th Imp B.A.C.

We journeyed to Daylight Corner, arriving about 9 pm. slept in hut used by sub as mess room.
Entry.88:
Daylight Corner

Weather wet. Getting ready for the road. Fritz as far back as one third of the way between the towns of Albert and Amiens.

Major gave us the dinkum oil of what we are to expect shortly, and we are to leave at 2.30am tomorrow.

Walked to Neuve Eglise and had a feed in the company of Adey, Da Costa.

Weather still dull. Raining heavily.

Fritz shelling Bailleul with H.O.
Entry.89:
On the road.

Reveille at 2.15am. journeyed to Poperinge and entrained at 7.30am . Passed through Hazebroack, Ca—tie, Melin, St.Pol, and Buiserbrouge, arrived at Doulens at 5pm.

Owing to heavy traffic train held up until 12 midnight. Feeling fairly tired.

Boys fairly happy under existing circumstances.

Raining very hard.

Ground fairly sodden.

Truck with old "Morse Code" aboard had a slight mishap – ran off line "Morse Code" fairly excited as a result of it.
Entry.90:
On the Road – Bycourt.

2am detrained at 2.30 am. and proceeded to our billets Rained very hard all the while.

The complete outfit whilst en route to billets at Orville, was drenched with rain.

We arrived at Orville at .15 am and after watering and feeding up, retired to bed for a little spell before moving up to the line. 

We are to "standby" to move up any hour.

Word came through that the 4th Divvie had smacked Fritz back four miles – heavy casualties.
Entry.91:
In Billets- Orville

Went down to Santos last night , with boys, had a great time, had quiet a good series of manoeuvres during morning and afternoon. 

Weather glorious

At 2 am. this morning Fritz paid us a visit and dropped quite a considerable number of bombs around the district.

After tea walked to Santos and had a feed with Ken Gunn.
Entry.92:
In Billet – Orville

Bombed during early hours of morning. No casualties. 

A great number of R.A.M.C. arrived enroute to line, from Italy.

During afternoon I performed the erroneous duty of Marker on Battery manoeuvres.

Weather beautiful.

Had a swim above the wier with Russell.

Went along to Santos with Ken Gunn.

Missed the boys so came home very early.

Met Adranne – "a bon petite Cherie"
Entry.93:
In Billet – Y.M.C.A. Orville

Spent morning in cleaning harness, and afternoon in excersising on hills.

Weather very wet, and cold.

Received p.c. from O.J. and Smithy received some mail from M.V.

Received a letter from A.R.T, 

Went up to Sav-on in evening with P.G.

Had the usual and spent an enjoyable evening.

Gunn still bed mate.

Rained heavily last night.

Had lecture by Major.
Entry.94:
In Billets – 7pm .12 mid on Road.

Spent morning cleaning up bits, and irons.

Left for exercise arrived back after dinner.

Great number of Tommies miving around village.

Went along to Sarton and had a snack; just finished when Percy G. arrived in breathless haste and announced the news that Battery was moving out.

Caught up Batt as they were moving out of village and at mid shell on road.
Entry.95:
Mid to 8 am. On Road ---houssoye? 

Arrived at Billet at 7.30 am after all night on the road. – very rough trip too. Rained throughout the night fairly heavily.

Watered horses at river. A few shells - high bursts of shrapnel over, Albert Amiens road.

Seager and Piper returned from Doullens.

Boys fairly bright under circumstances. 

.Awfully sorry I had to miss the company of Adianne.
Entry.96:
On Road - Bonnay

Reveille at 3.15 am on road at 4.30am. Weather cold but clear.

Pulled in to Bonnay at 7.15am.

Battery in action on ridge – Tommy I think.

Walked around village things in a horrible confusion of clothes and private property owing to place being evacuated hurriedly.

Assisted in laying lines to W.L. also in digging dugouts.

Saw five Fritzers planes brought down, and one of our burn. One Fritzer turned up road with M.G.

Ordered to report to , arrived after a rotten trip of 16 kilos at Blarney Ironville.
Entry.97:
Blaney Tronville. D.A.H.Q 

Met a great number of old companions at 5th Pioneer comp.

Worked on horse lines all morning, and set out for Bdge with despatches at 3.30pm.

Got drenched through before Corbey. Sheltered a little while there and met Jimmy Grant.

Arrived and delivered despatches received and set off again for ?d qrs.

Weather wet. Met Les Fuller in La Nevvillo. 15th bdge captured 1000 yds of trenches, about Corbie Sector.
Entry.98:
Blaney Tronville - D.A.H.Q.

Had a fairly busy day 

No lines.

Met Bob Bulcher, and a few other old companions including young Craven from the Oaks.

Rained hard throughout the day.

"Morse Code" looks fairly tired on the strength of his heavy work.

Fritz bombed the vicinity with some fairly nice bombs. He is also shelling the roads between Corbie and Fuillory
Entry.99:
Blaney Tronville D.R. 

Weather much about the same, fine during the morning – rained all the afternoon.

Fritz shelled fairly lightly, roads and villages.

Have so far not had a run to do today.

Wrote a few whzz bangs.

Fritz planes flew over chateau and home again attended by machine gun and anti fire 19th Batt captured Decaguaville
Entry.100:
Blaney Tronville. D.R.

Weather fine and clear.

Wemnt for a spin to Bonnay and Callanvelle. Had a talk with some Yankee Engineers on a Bridge job.

Bob Butcher came down – had the usual talk.

A few planes - a - la Fritz across after heavy guns.

Rumored that Fritz had captured Estairs and S-illo up Flanders way. I sincerely trust that such is not the case.
Entry.101:
Blaney Tronville D.R.

Weather fine. Went across country to Daours, La P--- Bussey and reconnoitred bridges and position for

retreat if necessary. This was carried out under Cap Mellor.

At 2 pm. We left Chateau for Bussey and stayed at new artillery Hdqs.

Plenty of taubes Gothas and etc. flying around unloading .N.16.C.

Heavy bombardment by Fritz.

Feeling fairly fagged.
Entry.102:
Bussey – La – Dours. D.R.

Weather glorious. During morning rode across to Pont – Noyelles, a Querrie had a look at bridges there incomplete.

In the afternoon saw a very spectacular feat in air – one Fritzer dropped.

Heavy bomb raid by Gothas at 5am.

Rode across country to Bonnay and reported at Bty for mail. – received 15 letters and a parcel of socks.

Another bomb raid per Fritz at 7.30pm.
Entry.103:
Bussy – la – Dours. D.R.

Spent a farily quiet day. Heard the bombardment for a Fritz hop over, and witnessed the usual fireworks.

Weather wet and miserable.

Fritz did a fair amount of bombing on Daours.

He also shelled that region fairly heavily.

Inspection and instruction on map reading.

Reconnoitred bridges during afternoon and instructed the Bombadier in his alternative routes for necessitity
Entry.104:
Bussy – la – Daours D.R.

Weather dull, - no rain in day - rained all night.

Witnessed a good horse race for five pounds over 5 furlongs – easy win for Hdqrs . 4 lengths. Bob Butcher came around had the usual yap.

Tom Gallaghers horse wounded in off hind with shrapnel.

Fritz put down a fairly heavy barrage on Abinqy Rd , and lengthened to Daours – Rumours of pay tomorrow; Had a win at midnight.
Entry.105:
Bussy – la – Daours. D.R.

Spent a very quiet morning during the afternoon rode to Bonnay via Querrie, Pont Noyelle, La Ne—and received a fair quantity of mail.

Borrowed a few francs from Ken Gunn.
Entry.106:
Bussy – la – Dours - D.R.

Horse looks queer, played cards until midnight – won

Spent a very quiet day.

Inspection during the morning.
Entry.107:
Bussy – la – Daours. D.R.

Everything fairly quiet.

Rode across to Camon and had a decent feed.

Went on to Amiens. Cathedral does not look too well, under Fritz`s bombardment.

Weather very wet.

Fritz in Baille-- latest.
Entry.108:
Bussy – la – Daours D.R.

At 6.30 am I received a call went across to Bonnay, Battery moved.

Came home and had a quiet day.

Went out on a run to Blaney Tronville and La Motte, during night 

Fritz tried a stunt against 41st Batt, - he certainly came a cropper.

Played cards until midnight – won.
Entry.109:
Bussy – la – Daours. D.R.

Very quiet day. Groomed old Mick and had a go at harness – looks better.

Went down to river and had a swim

During afternoon had a swim.

Sleet fell altho the day was a bright one.

Scottie fell into the mud pond.

Inspection by Lt Booth on the staff.

Satisfactory.
Entry.110:
Bussy – la –Daours D.R.

French made a small advance down in Montideder region.

Had a despatch for Bdge Hdqs, rode over accompanied by Jackson 13th Bdge.

Seven hundred cases of gassed men recently .

Fritz having a whack at Bethune.

Weather fairly cool but very nice.

Planes over all night, and they dropped a few of the best in village.

Relieved sick on Bty 

Bloomsbury parte pour Batterié –
Entry.111:
Bussy – la – Daours. D.R.

Went on shift – 24 hours at office, had a fairly lare amount of work to do on duty.

Weather glorious. Wrote several letters.

Played the game – lost

Spoke to Birdwood who recognised me. Baron Von ? one of Germany`s air cracks brought down by M.G. fire from 53rd Bty machine guns.

-Good work.
Entry.112:
Bussy – la – Daours D.R.

Went out on reconnaissance with Russell and shewed him plenty of the back areas, - second positions.

Weather beautiful, fine and clear.

Fritz dropped his advance bombs for supper last night.

Fritz shelling lightly back areas. Cleaned up all my saddle appointments.

Wrote seven letters.

Bomb went up to Aubigny on Buzzer Unit.
Entry.113:
Bussy – la - Daours. D.R.

Inspection by Capt. Muller.

German spy caught clad in 5th Divvie Pioneer rig.

Weather beautiful 

Made some souveners during spare time, also a bush vice.

Rode across and saw Allan, Penner, Bob and Barnay at 5th M.G.s Coy camp

Some of the Batteries have been slightly gassed.

7.50 pm. Three bombing planes turned up the en route to Amiens.
Entry.114:
Bussy – la – Dours D.R.

3.50 am. Aroused by heavy drum fire in the region of Montididier – packed up kit, lines went at 5.15am.

Stand to until noon.

Weather dull and misty.

Battery W.L. all returned to Franvillers, and are having a fairly rough spin.

Had a run through Bonnay at 1pm. A very putrid sight arms and legs and mules scattered over the roads in a horrible array.

6ath Battery caught coming out of village, mules left on road.

Fritz shelling fairly heavily
Entry.115:
Bussy – la – Daours. D.R.

Had a tour to Bonnay after inspection, - received new gas bag.

1200 Fritz`s captured at Villers Brettonvibne. Some fine big fellows amongst them also some youngsters very heavy fighting for village of Villers Brettonvibne.

Fifteenth Bdge did the damage.

Rode up to W.L. at Franvillers and had a yap with boys. James knocked in thigh. Fleming, Bill Aldred, Davies and three others killed.

Weather mists.
Entry.116:
Bussy – la – dours. D.R.

Gallaghar returned to unit. For non delivery of despatches. 

Mounted instection at 10am.

Weather wet. New runner for 113th arrived.

Had a run down to Bonnay.

Fred Aldred`s brother died of wounds.

Received a little mail one from Roy.

Cant understand why folks don`t get letters over in Blighty.

April 1918

Saturday 27

Bussy – la – Daours. D.R.

Weather misty. 500 Fritz`s grabbed by 14th Bgd. English landing at Zeebrugge, - first public of news !

Very heavy fighting up north and at Hangard. French lost Hangard after seven counter attacks. 

Another inspection. Cleaned up saddle again
Entry.117:
Battalion went through.

French lost Kemmel. Whole division being wiped
Entry.118:
Bussy – la – Daours. D.R.

Weather wet throughout day. Rode across to La Neuville as guide to a new runner.

Met wagon lines in new position out from Pont Noyette. Fritz shelling village with gas.

Rode up to W.L. with wire and cigarettes, in the evening.

Fairly heavy shelling in the region of Viller Bettnovino, numerous tanks passed through .

Met Charlie.
Entry.119:
Bussy – la – Daours D.R.

Weather wet

4am. Fritz made a very heavy attack at Villers Bretnovino. Gained 100 yds.
Entry.120:
Mobile Vet section moved out.

At 5 pm an enemy aeroplane was brought down intact and the pilot and observer captured.

The machine was intact and I believe belonged to the circus of the German Flying Corps.

Heavy stunt commenced but ended early.
Entry.121:
Bussy – la – Daours. D.R.

The aeroplane brought down yesterday was one fo Fritz`s latest, and seated four persons.

A bullet through petrol tank caused its descent.

Weather indifferent.

Had a few bombs about midday from a couple of Gothas. One brought down.

Having a little 

Received a parcel from
Entry.122:
Bussy La Daours.

Bill Aldred died of wounds at 11th C.C.S.

Sympathised with Fred.

Weather fine.

A great amount of air fighting one of us was dropped handily, and another of Fritz came a wallop.

Two more Fritzs dropped.

Received 13 letters from home and elsewhere in Aust very welcome they were . one from Roy very cheerful . Going to Southall Hospital 

Rained at 10 pm.
Entry.123:
Bussy la Daours

Weather fine, Had a hurry up run to Bonnay and called at battery on way back.

Received payment first for some considerable time, very welcome indeed. Col Caddy received C.D.C.

Slept in General`s room and learnt quite a considerable amount of very important things while acting as bodyguard.

Weather fine plenty of flying. Bombs again around

here.
Entry.124:
Bussy-la-Daours

Had a run to F.H.B. at Bonnay. Saw three Fritz`s dropped near P.O.W. camp, from La Neuvelle.

Received several letters,two from cousin Mary and one from Jack Harvey, also several others including one from Geo Drury.

Received also, a letter from Adrienne.

Paid Ken Gunn 15. Rect Alex Mouab, at battery baggage lines had an agreeable talk. He is in in 24th A.S.C. 3rd divvy.

Weather glorious.
Entry.125:
Bussy-la-Daoures

Fred Aldred was over in morning and I paid him 20. Avec mercies.

Weather glorious

Had the usual day on duty at Generals office and spent the usual uninteresting time.

One Fritzer brought down at La Neuville.

Rode across to Bonnay with a despatch to 14th and 150 Bdes.

Had a run into line near - horse cut a little about legs.

Arrived home 12.30am 

A few
Entry.126:
Bussy-la-Daours

Weather clear, but very muggy.

Cleaned up all my gear for saddle and my equipment.

Boys are all very well and Ginger looks a little better. Paraded to M.O. for his inspection and had his legs dressed.

Paraded before Muller in evening and he dished out the usual yap.

Received a letter from Cousin and certainly liked the news
Entry.127:
Bussy-la-Daours

Had a run out to 19th Bdges Hdqrs. also to 150th Bdges Hdqrs.

Had a rough spin owing to condition of ground and horse.

Rained very heavily all day

Had Ginger dressed by V.serg. and he looks a little better

Ken Gunn came across to Btry Hdqrs. He is looking very well.

Looked them up whilst on a run to Villers Bretnoo.

.
Entry.128:
Bussy-la—Daours

Weather wet, heavy rain all day. Had a run to Bonnay via Corbie and Daours.

Chestnut gassed in both legs, shot as a result of injuries.

Ken Gunn and Pea paid me a visit during evening.

Borrowed a large reel of D.3, and sent same to Batterie.

Had a couple of eufs avc du pang, du beure et coffee, at Le Maison des Madame Isobel.
Entry.129:
Dussy-la-Daours

Still raining, had a run at midnight to Villers Brettoneaux, plenty of the Bosche dead still unburied.

Paid a visit to Jame`s grave and took a snap of same.

Wrote to Uncle Will, Mum, Toots and Adrienne also Ray.

Slight gas bombardment at Corbie and Fuilloy

Met an American from Florida in Engineers.
Entry.130:
Bussy-la-Daours

Thank goodness the old juice has stopped at last.

At pm. Had another run out to Bonnay.

Weather still uncertain.

Fritz shelling slightly 

New horse now

Met Charlie Frey and had a little pow pow .

Bill boozed badly , visited Madame.

Boys very cheerful under influence of rum issue.
Entry.131:
Bussy-la-Daours

Glorious weather.

Had the usual journey at 4 pm, to Lailly Le Sec, via Vaux sur Somme and Corbie.

During afternoon drifted out avec Muller, to Querrie Pont Noyelle, and La Neuvelle, as Mounted Orderley.

Wrote a French epistle to Adrienne, aided by Lemon, at Madame Isobel.

Harry came in from Aubigny.
Entry.132:
Bussy-la-Daours

Paid a visit to Eglise with bob.

During afternoon acted as a guide to an American Sergeant and rode across to Glisy with him.

Weather wet. On arrival home found all the boys including Kenn Gunn, and Albie Garford, the former with my mail.

One parcel from Eva one from Roy and one from Toots. Also a few letters.
Entry.133:
Bussy-la Daours

Worked at building a small protective wall for splinters

Weather glorious.

On duty at General`s office during afternoon and evening, and all night. Sketched two maps of Egypt and Suvla Bay for my American pal.

Intend to visit him at some time or other. Spent a very quiet evening.
Entry.134:
Bussy-la-Daours d.y.

Finished rampart for moke, trotted same out for a feed of grass. Wounds opened again .Bill boozed again. Weather glorious. Rode across to see Walton Pip but as he was out came home via W.L. without seeing his cheerful Received a letter mail. Am due for a run to Villers Brettoneaux again to expect Fritz across tonight avec bombs, an ideal day. Rode the chestnut out.
Entry.135:
Bussy-la-Dours d-y

At 4 am Fritz arrived at our little district – well loaded . No military damage.

Weather today – glorious. Rode across to Bonnay, and had a swim in the big pool at Querrie. Temperature reached to 95 º at midday.

At 7 pm Fritz`s waves commenced , and numbering twelve visited Amiens . Artillery very active at 10 pm.

May 1918

Wednesday 15

Bussy-la-Daours

Weather – very hot, and muggy, evening fairly mild. Wrote one or two letters. Acted as guide to several Tommies. 

2 98 DAC changed places at 6 pm with the 13th FAB.

Paid 60 francs and had a run across to Villers Bretonneaux.

At 9pm Fritz visited Amiens, Querrie and Daours. Had a swim during afternoon. A
Entry.136: Division chap was drowned in the big pool.
Entry.137:
Bussy –la-Daours

Went for a swim during the morning.

Weather very warm, with no breeze. 

Had a morning run to Fuilloy at 7 am

At 7 pm Fritz commenced the first aerial bombardment since we have been in the village. 

We had a frisky time under the strain, a very big pool down by the Daours church greatly patronised during the heat of the day.
Entry.138:
Bussy –la-Daours

At 3 am Fritz came across in full swing and unloaded some tens into the district.

Weather very warm but a little cooler than yesterday.

Mounted parade at 9.30 am. Chestnut getting better very rapidly – will soon be fit to ride.

Rode across to La Neville at 10.30 pm.

Have received no mail for quite a considerable time. Fritz shelled Daours.
Entry.139:
Bussy –la-Daours

Weather very warm, received a little present of eufs from a pal.

A heavy thunder storm broke about 3 pm which greatly freshened things. At 6.30 pm went for a swim and swam Gen`s horse.

At 7 pm Fritz shelled village fairly severely with HV, HE and gas .

9.30 pm Run to Bonnay a little rough.

4.30 pm returned from run. Fritz still shelling . Plenty of bombs during night.
Entry.140:
Bussy –la-Daours

3 am Was aroused by the detonations of bombs and gas shells, now damage whatever.

Had a midnight toot to Villers Bretnoeaux.

Weather beautiful. Swam three horses during day. had old Ginger dressed. Ken Gunn paid me a little visit and had the usual eufs.

Won a few francs at the old game.
Entry.141:
Bussy –la-Daours

Weather beautiful. Had an inspection at 9am by Bdge Major, Received orders to promenade to my unit and stand by there as an emergency.

Should a hostile bombardment take place to report immediately. At 3 am this morning an aerial torpedo fell on a B,A.C`s Lines – made a mess.

Arrived at W.L. at 3.30 pm and reported to Capt Redmond.

Ran to Fuilloy during the morning.
Entry.142:
Bussy –la-Daours

Wagon Lines for Battery.

Weather fine. Did the 4 to 5.30 am on the phone. 

Fritz dropped four close to us at 11.30pm last night. Cleaned my harness, like a new set. Went for a swim with Ken .

Wrote several letters in the evening whilst on shift, 10 to 12.30 am

Burglar Lawrence and Abl Garfott arrived home from L`aison, at Vaire. 

Sent 50 francs to O.J. 

Saw a decent football match during the evening between "C" Battery and Q.R.H.A.

N
Entry.143:
Battery Wagon Lines.

Ken Gunn went up to Guns, and O.B.Walker came down, also Ernie Halligan.

Went down to the Lake for a little swim during morning . Russell arrived during afternoon he looks very well.

At 9.30 pm Fritz dropped at bomb on a C" charger dump up at Freshencourt.

The whole countryside was illuminated. 

Fritz dropped a few shells across the village of Pont Noyelles.
Entry.144:
Battery W.L.

Weather dull and windy. Wind from N .W. with plenty of bite in it.

Fritz put a few into Querrie, Received a letter from Aunt Ellie, an Aunt I did not know I possessed.

Gunn down for a run. Knipe still indisposed think he`s swinging the lad.

Had a run across to Bussy, and interviewed Simonde and Solange.

More bombs tonight.
Entry.145:
Battery W.L.

Weather rotten, rain and a very cold wind. Fritz bumped one or two around the district. Smithy and Adey visited the home.

Purchased several items of groceries for guns and gave them to Smithy. Malcom to L`aison for three days, Knipe very ill? Lofty Hallwood received shell shock from a local shell. 

Had the 2 to 4 this morning.
Entry.146:
Battery W.L.

Fritz put a lucky one into some Labor Corps and accounted for 35 killed, 60 casualties altogether.

Weather still dull but an improvement on yesterday. Knipe quite well today. Received a mag from Eileen. Wrote Mother and E. 

Commenced a recreation dug out under surveillance of Y.M.C.A. representative. 

Cleaned two saddles and received a visit from Andrews, also Tich Rice. Worked on dug out.
Entry.147:
Battery W.Lines

Weather glorious, nice and fair, no cold wind. 

Albert Garfott still down with Trench Fever.

Fritz came across early with his bombs and shells and illuminated the countryside with their splashes.

Finished the Y.M.C.A. dugout at 9.30 pm

Went for a swim with Albert and Ernie to the pool.

Fritz put wind up avec bombard avec aeroplane.

C`est la Guerre.
Entry.148:
Battery W.Lines.

Weather pretty decent.

Wrote Stell.

Went during afternoon for the usual swim. 

Albie a little better.

Knipe professes to be ill.

Percy Grayling visited the lines at 4.30 pm. 

Heard today that Archie Innes was wounded recently.

"Gibbie" is also in hospital 

The Y.M.C.A. hut or rather dugout opened with much entertaining speechmaking and singing. Fritz planes avc bombs as usual;.

Fritz shelling Pont Nooyelle and Querrie fairly regularly.
Entry.149:
Battery W.Lines.

Weather fine but fairly cool. Received a letter from Clar, enclosing some splendid snaps of the family. Also received a letter from "Toots" a beauty. 

Fairly heavy bombardment during morning.

Wrote several letters.

Help to complete construction of Y.M.

Cleaned steelwork of harness.

One or two fine air fights resulting in odds even over Corbie. 1 of ours 1 of theirs. Heard rumors of Fritz`s attack up North near Lochre. Good news.
Entry.150:
Battery W.Lines.

Weather beautiful, very warm, had the usual dip in lake avec Ernest. Walked across to old billet and stayed with the boys.

Purchased a dozen eggs at 4d each, broke nine as the result of a fall from a bicycle. Received four parcels. Of small dimensions. One from O.J. one from Mary, encore from L.O.L. and again from Miss Hawker. 

No bombs tonight; noticed a heavy fall on Amiens
Entry.151:
Battery W.Lines. posted Noyelles

Weather very nice indeed, had two swims in Lake very enjoyable indeed. Wrote four letters and acted as M.O. during day. Should have visited Andy but was called away early in afternoon and did not arrive home until late.

Percy Grayling arrived as usual from O.P.

Walker and Knipe for three days F.O.O. and L`aison respectively.

11.35 pm Fritz putting a few down on the villages in the district. Stan Laurence had a close shave at W.L..when going
Entry.152:
Battery W.Lines. near Pont Noyelles.

12.30 am Came off shift relieved by Scottie Malcom.

Weather delightful, pleasantly warm. Had customary swim.

Met Alex Francis who is off to a "poisoners" school at Pont Remy. He`s in luck right enough.

Bombs during the night and a few shells. Fritz having a little "stunt" down south near Soissons – seems to be successful, Rheims fell to the Hun today. He is up against a large body of troops.
Entry.153:
Battery W.Lines. near Pont Noyelles

The fourth Division relieved two Bdges of the 5th Inf this morning at 10 am.

Weather glorious.

Whilst on a "run" came across John Mc Farlane Lt` Jove but he does look merry and bright and has beaucoup damn fine fellow officers.

Had a nice "nip" or so from his Ex.

Went out for a ride in the evening – toward Allonville but could not see too much of friend Walton "PiP’

Met Frank Johnson today, he looks to be in the Pink.

Fritz has drifted along some 30 kilos.
Entry.154:
Battery W.Lines. near Pont Noyelles

Beautiful weather. Jack H. did not arrive as I expected. had usual swim. After 

Church Service had a practice on the piano salvaged from the debris of Corbie. Numbers of brass instruments have appeared as also has a violin, clarinet and mandolin. The orchestra is having a flying start. At 11.30 am, Fritz commenced dropping salvoes of H and Gas down in the gully. He continued to do so until 12.30 am, when he suddenly ceased. O.B. and Knipe returned. Cpl Kelly down for a spell.
Entry.155:
Battery W.Lines. near Pont Noyelles

Weather delighful. I notice one R.H.A. Battery has pulled out on to the Footer Ground. Perhaps the gas last night was too much for them. Fritz is well down the Marne once again , - pas bien neuvill, Streaked into Bussy three times.

Met Jack Harvey and spent a very salubrious evening. Had a glorious old gossip about things in general. he looks ever so fit. Spent a very quiet anniversary of departure from Australia for second time. Three years today, gee whiz.
Entry.156:
Battery W.Lines. near Pont Noyelles

Weather glorious. Mother`s birthday today. I wonder how my dearest friend is. Went along to see John during the day.

About 9.30 am, we received a surprise, in the form of an

an aeroplane of the fighting type armed with three

machine guns (named Sopworth Dolphin, flown 

by a young Indian Prince Lt Welinkar .Twas was a dandy

little machine. Our major entertained the pilot during the 

day and as the machine was not repaired by sunset the

pilot does not leave until the

morning.
Entry.157:
Battery W.Lines. near Pont Noyelles

Weather stills hold good, with the clear skies and warm days. Had the usual dip with the boys.

Rode to Daours with despatches and returning called in to see Jack – he was not in. Discovered that Sig Coy had packed their kit and partied to Coisy¸beyond Cardonette.

Had a jolly decent concert during the evening, attended by quite a number of fellows. Major gave us the "Geebung Polo Club," The items were very very decent. Keith Meillon visited . Had my wool shorn off.
Entry.158:
Battery W.Lines. near Pont Noyelles

Weather beautiful. Received a packet from Mrs Felton, a letter.

Very pleased to read that BIlling M.P. was acquitted. Seems there is a sorry state of affairs in the English aristocracy. 

Visited and sang at a concert in the open, near 113th Hows Waggon Lines. Quite a good concert, no lack of artists. 

Ran across Robbie, North and Theo Meillon. Smith arrived from Guns for the afternoon.

Scottie Malcolm went up to the guns
Entry.159:
Battery W.Lines. near Pont Noyelles

Weather very mild, cloudy. New balloon rigged at rear of W.L.. Had usual swim, Halligan and Walker to guns. "Don Ack", and Percy G. returneth.

Just like old times again. 

At 9.45 line went under pressure of shell burst.

Received message from Guns that Sgt Wigg, a new Sgt from D.A.C. Corp Ness. Bdr Moulton, had received Blighties. also a Gun, no name through yet. Gun also badly bent. Shell burst in pit next to Spook`s pit. Received a letter form O.J. 

Registered my diary, under Capt Edwards Censorship,

hope it arrives home all correct.
Entry.160:
Battery W.Lines. near Pont Noyelles.

Weather very fine. Visited Jack Harvey, had some very 

refreshing drinks

Rode across to Bonnay for a feed and certainly had one

sang at Concert in 

Y.M.C.A. pretty successful turn out. Had a very enjoyable

swim with Don

Ack, P.E and Trail

Red Palmer worries about something.

Inspected a programme of events for tomorrow`s sports.

Met North and Robbie at 113th Lines.
Entry.161:
Battery W.Lines. near Pont Noyelles

Weather dull, and fairly close. Attended Church Parade

in the morning, had a nice swim after lunch.

Sports very successful l"F" Sub second 15 pts. "C" first

20 pts.

Bob and Mick Fargo rode very well in Y.C. and Bending 

races.

"F" Sub won wrestling on horseback.

Walked over to Bussey with "Pip" C, and "Don Ack". Had

some eufs. Met John on way home testing? Mills Bombs.
Entry.162:
Battery W.Lines. near Pont Noyelles

Weather dull, heavy rains. No swim today.

Charlie Adey a little better. 

Received a long letter from Len Clements, - quite a

decent one.

Practiced for concert, postponed until Thursday owing t

heavy rains. At 10pm Fritz dropped his barrage, lasted 

until 11.10 pm. A beautiful display of fireworks.

Regst. Another 40 francs to O.J. Expect to go out for a

spell very shortly.

Had a decent yap with Percy. Posted art studies from La

Vie Parision to M.J.Wh. also wrote Ead.
Entry.163:
Battery W.Lines. near Pont Noyelles

Weather fairly cool, not feeling exactly brilliant. 

Went for a swim with P.L.C. Charlie Adey got up, and

seems to be a little 

Better. Went down with trench fever during the 

afternoon, - feel pretty rotten, 

Percy Gray being also effected, he has the same

complaint.

Saw John Harvey on the road to his home. Expect to go out for a spell on the 18th. only a rumor so far
Entry.164:
Battery W.Lines. near Pont Noyelles

Weather dull and dismal.

Fritz shelled presumably after balloon but without any

result. A few lobbed 

ahead of W. Lines. H.V. 4. H.E.

Laid up throughout day did not do my shift last night.

Feeling rotten on Strength of Trench fever. 

Percy Gray being 103 degrees. Myself 102 degrees, not

too dusty.

Can`t admit any tendency on my part to do any ragtime 

dancing as I am at present.
Entry.165:
Battery W.Lines. near Pont Noyelles

Weather cool and very fine indeed, Smithy not too good

at guns, with same complaint as myself.

Still confined to bed, feel a little better, but very tender all

over body.

Peter promised medicine so far none to hand. Percy 

Grayling much better. I still feel very queer on the face of 

things.

Had some horrible dreams. Costa arrive back at midday.

He also is pretty crook. With this chronic complaint.
Entry.166:
Battery W.Lines. Pont Noyelles

Weather changing, laid up throughout day and last night. Feel very stiff and sore through being in bed.

D.A.C. and H.A.C.sports commenced. Line went under pressure of shell mended same

Received no mail at all. Smithy and Ken Gunn still hors-de-combat at Guns.

Mr Mann arrived from guns looking like a hero. Boils over his face and head caused the decoration. Mr Ken down for the afternoon.
Entry.167:
Battery W.Lines. near Pont Noyelles

Weather wet, during morning fine and clear, in afternoon. 

Had a very enjoyable concert at W.L. a very good tenor,

and ebcontionist. The Star items. O`Kelly the tenor,

sang several very sweet songs. Polished up old

"Acks" bit and irons "Smithy still feeling bad.

Had a run to Bussy; and saw folks there.

Second divvie pioneers and 5th Bdge came out. Met

Harry Rich now Lt Rich, - congratulated him on his

progress. 

Received 3 letters from Australia 20/4/18
Entry.168:
Battery W.Lines. Pont Noyelles

Very peculiar weather prevails at present. Our 

experience here today was quite a typical tropical one.

Did usual shift on phone. 6-8 – and then

noon, thoroughly cleaned my saddle etc.

During afternoon Battery sports was held, my sub carried

the highest points for the day, winning the tug-o-war on

foot and horseback. I was in both teams. 

They also won the Rescue race, high jump, and Bending

race. Received a few letters one from Home.

June 1918

Monday 17

Battery W.Lines. Pont Noyelles

Weather very decent, bright and sunny. 14th Bdge went 

in to reserve during morning.

Jack passed by the camp at about 9.30am.
Entry.169:
Bdge went out. They take the 14ths old camping

grounds. 

Looked up the whereabouts of Gun Adam, and am going 

to visit him tomorrow. Feel moderately pleased at the

prospect of meeting my dear Elie`s brother.

Received one or two letters included a schedule of the

contents of my 

wardrobe in Blighty. Went to a concert in the evening

with D.Ack.
Entry.170:
Battery W.Lines. nr. Pont Noyelles

Weather unsettled. Paid 100 Francs to-day. Played two

up and dropped the whole issue, as well as 50 others.

Fritz plane fired one of our balloons, one observer

parachute failed to open, but he fell on a tree and came 

out with a few scratches. The other chap 

landed in Bty W.Lines and had an explosive bullet drilled

through his side. He seemed just about done when he

landed. 

Met Gun Adam outside Querrie.
Entry.171:
Battery W.Lines. Pont Noyelles

Weather wet, heavy rain throughout day. Gun came

across in evening, we went for a long stroll and

managed to crib some eggs, quite a very pleasant

supper.

Percy Grayling also visited canteen and purchased syrup

Quaker oats, milk and one or two other necessities.

Weather still raining .

Expect to leave at any time now. Officers of the 42nd

Battery were

across here this morning.
Entry.172:
Battery W.Lines. Pont Noyelles

Weather wet and miserable. orders for Rgt and Centre

Section to pull out at 11.p.m. tonight . 

peculiar coincidence that rain always falls when we pull 

out.

Gun Adam paid me a visit at W.L. we went for a long

stroll to Bussy, Querrie and Pont Noyelles. Had a very

nice food , and awbon parle.

Grayling, D a Costa left, Charlie Adey has gone to a

school as instructor to a Tommy School, at Havre
Entry.173:
Battery W.Lines. Pont Noyelles

Weather still raining and a very driving mist with a cold

breeze.

Went up to Bty with a horse for Smithy.

Left section pulled out at 9 pm and we eventually arrived

at a small village on the outskirts of Amiens, where we

billeted for the night.

Smithy and Gun slightly inebriated under the flue of Vin

rouge et Vin Blanc. 

Still enroute at midnight.
Entry.174:
On the Road. Bourdon.

Weather wet and miserably cool. Cleaned harness in the

morning generally swanking up for the road tomorrow.

Walked to a neighboring village, where we spent a fairly

Convivial evening in the company of Smithy and Gunn.

Believe we pull out at can`t say with any

certainty.

Feel fairly happy.
Entry.175:
On the road, Flexicourt.

Weather fine, with no rain whatever. Plenty of dust though passed through several decent villages.

Pulled in to a nice camp at 2 pm.

Smithy on police duty .Walked with Smithy and Gunn to ,had some very decent eufs, viewed some bon mamselles .

Fritz aeroplane bombed village near by,, rather large bombs.
Entry.176:
Minday 24

On the road, Ebevnville.

Weather very dusty, cold winds. Left billets at 7.30 am. And pulled into final camp at 12.50 pm.

Walked into Pont Remf with Smithy, Gunn and . Had a very decent snack in a farm close to railway station. Walked home through Friedcourt.

Reg Harris and a few others returned to Battery. Teddie Dunn also.
Entry.177:
In Billets. Erronville

Weather fine and clean

Usual routine of stables etc. watered near by. 

Walked with Smithy to Camoun through Bailleul. Enjoyed a decent feed in a decent shack. Village about 10 Kilos distant. 

From top of hill flashes of bombs 

About Flexicourt way.

Received parcel from Dot Watson also one from O.J.
Entry.178:
In Billets. Erronvillle

Weather glorious a perfect day.

Rode to Abbeville with Smithy as horseholder. He is the luckiest person I know to be granted ten days leave to Paris.

Abbeville is slightly bent in places owing to the attention paid to it by Fritzer planes.

Paid a visit to my friend of yesterday Suzanne , and had some oeuf good mangy.
Entry.179:
In Billets. Erronville

Weather fine and clear. Had the usual daily routine with horse and bycycles also wire and phones ,

Drifted along to see my friend Suzanne on the Hellencount Road.

Worked for awhile at the farm, had a beautiful spread of roast fowl peas and potatoes, also strawberries and cream.

Fritz bombed Abbeville.
Entry.180:
Erronville. – On the road

Weather glorious , fine and clear. All kinds of rumours prevalent as to moving up again.

Orders to prepare for evacuation in a half hours time have arrived.

Packed Smithy`s kit and my own and set off to bid my friend au Revoir.

Left Battery W.L. at 8.45 pm and arrived at just before midnight. At 12 midnight we were still on the road near Longpre.
Entry.181:
Bourdon. On the road

Pulled into our W. Lines at 2.30 am, feeling pretty tired too. 

Ken Gunn not looking very well and does not profess to be too well. Billeting party left at 11.30 am.

Weather splendid walked into Hanzest in the evening with Ton Code, had a chat with one or two folk there and a snack.

Pulled out at 9 pm for . Had a spendid trip all night and arrived at Poulonville at 3.50 am. On Sunday morning.

French advanced 7 kilos at Montdider.
Entry.182:
Poulonville. – On road and at Bty Posit.

Pulled into School yard at 3.50 am. After a farily solid trip all night. The road Palmer, Evayling and Garfott to Bty position 1.25 C.

We proceeded at 8 pm for Battery position with the guns.

Arrived at position at 2.30am
Entry.183: Just arrived when we received two salvoes of whizz bangs. 1 horse killed and Cpl Kelly slightly wounded – Mr Koens horse also slightly wounded.
Entry.184:
Vaux sur Somme.1st Bty Posit.

Arrived with guns at 2.30 am, after a fairly long march.

There seems to be a big concentration of artillery heavy and otherwise all along the front . Rumored a big stunt to come off on the 4th.

Weather very warm and fine.

Walked to W.L. with despatch and walked home again – 18 kilos altogether. Ken and I are making dugout for two – rotten position.
Entry.185:
Vaux sur Somme.1st Bty Posit.

Weather glorious, wwarm with a very gentle breeze. Ken and I prepared our little whiz Bang proof home, - not of very much value.

Tom Code volunteers to hop the bags with the F.O.O. on the morning of the stunt.

Registration etc. the duties of the day. Slept very cold last night. Pas bon.

Received a letter from Mother and Adrienne. Looking forward to shoot which commences tomorrow morning.
Entry.186:
Vaux sur Somme.1st Bty Position.

Weather glorious , fine and clear: Received a long letter from Mother. Wrote one or two to different folk.

Final preparations made for tonight`s stunt . Tom Code

and Da Costa are to hop 	the bags tonight. I wish them

both the very best of luck. 

Georgee Baker and Fitters North to hospital with Trench

fever.I 

am Assistant linesman in the company of Ken Gunn for the stunt.
Entry.187:
Vaux sur Somme.1st Battery Position.

Weather fine. At 3.10 am the preliminary bombardment opened. After 5 minutes bombarding the Barrage went forward. The infantry reached their final objective at - am and the tanks came in at 5.4am. Result gained 2050 yds. Captured 13 officers including 2 C.O.s 1400 prisoners, 90 machine G. and 46 T.M..s

Adey and Costa came home at 8 am.

Tom gave me a very good watch and several other small curios. At 10.25 pm. SOS from Cevisy and repeated at 11pm again. Both attacks failed.
Entry.188:
Vaux sur Somme.1st Battery Position

At 1am this morning Villery Brettoneaux and Hamel were burning. Captures in this Sector now mount to 100 M.E. and 42 Officers, as well as the prisoners and material captured yesterday.

Very quiet throughout the day, had a few minutes fishing, received a letter from Toots.

Weather glorious.at 10.40 pm Fritz counter attacked and we received the S.O.S. the attack failed. At 2.35 am Fritz again counter attacked, we received another S.O.S. Attack failed
Entry.189:
Vaux sur Somme.1st Bty. Position

At 2.35 a, Fritz again counter attacked, we answered S.O.S. attack failed.

During the morning went forward with the officers to select a new possie – found one and left for same during the evening. Weather fine and warm.

At 11.30 am arrived at new possie, originally held by 150 Bdge. Laid O.M.. Line and established and communication O.B. Walker arrived from W.L. Palmer and Ken left a school commencing tomorrow. Paid 40 francs .

Albert is now B. Clerk
Entry.190:
Vaux sur Somme.2nd Battery Position

Laid gun line and fixed up a couple of emergency lines to

53rd and 55th, in company of Tom Code.

Laid a line to O. Pot. 4pm and generally squared up

everything.

Weather fine. Fritz still shelling Vaux and the vicinity.

Battery registered Heard today Mr Sheedy was coming

back to the Bty. Smithy arrived back from Paris leave, up

to time. Hear we are only in for a week. Capt Nicholson

a little better. 

Had a letter from Bully, he`s going home.
Entry.191:
Vaux sur Somme.2nd Bty. Position

At 1am Fritz was shelling on a duty shoot, all round district. At 12.20 am all the guns opened for a stunt, of what I do not know. 

Smithy came up to position and I was very glad to see him looking so well and happy. 

Halligan went out to L`aison at Hamel with Mr. Kerr.

Wrote several letters for Smithy and myself. Had a feed of chips made by Tom.

Had a heavy thunderstorm
Entry.192:
Vaux sur Somme.2nd Bty.Position

Weather bright and clear during morning, aftenoon rained very heavily, and was still raining at midnight. Have had no word from Ken Gunn, as yet. 

Mr Mays left for Sig School at St Evatien, the same one as Ken has gone down to. O.Beer, commenced work on the dugout`s spare entrance. Fritz and a decent duty shoot. Won 100 francs at poker, suppose I will lose same tomorrow.

Repaired two breaks on the O.P. line Major returned
Entry.193:
Vaux sur Somme.2nd Bty.Position

Weather unsettled. Went for water with Smithy and met Ron Powell who has just reported from Australia after being returned home from Egypt suffering with rupture. Met one or two other lads also.

at 8.30am. Two Fritz planes came across to look at the country. Fritzer balloons active all day. Worked on dugout entrance and completed digging same at 9 pm.

Played cards until 2 am, when I then went on shift until 6am
Entry.194:
Vaux sur Somme.2nd Bty.Position

Weather wet and fine during the evening.

Went out salvaging wine with Tom, collected and reeled about 2¼ miles of D.3. some brand new stuff.

Walked too Welcome Wood with the Major and Percy Grayling. Major selected new battery position, more advanced than this. Have no idea when we shall move into same. Received letter from J.McIlerney.

Wrote two lengthy letters for Smithy. Halligan returned from Batt L`aison.

Played cards until twelve remained on duty until 4 am.
Entry.195:
Vaux- sur- Somme.2nd Bty.Position

4 am. Weather fair to good. Fritz doing a big duty shoot on right.

At 9 am the weather became very much cooler.

Salvaged one mile of wire, and had a fair amount of graft.

Finished plenty of graft on dugout, 

Played cards and finished a fair amount of cash.

Wrote letters to Marguette and for Smithy.
Entry.196:
Vaux- sur- Somme.2nd Bty.Position

Weather fair but cloudy. Our balloons very active. Hear we are being relieved by 3rd Division to be correct the 30th Battery. Played cards – no luck. At 5pm Five Fritzer planes came across our lines. At this time our balloons were well up forward with no fighting plans guarding them. At this time, only three planes were visible. Two planes made for a balloon each and caught them, bringing them both down in flames. A beautiful piece of work
Entry.197:
Vaux- sur- Somme.2nd Bty.Position

The weather was as it usually is, wet and miserable. Our relief arrived here and we are moving today at about 10 pm.

At 6 pm we left our old position and journeyed via Heilly and Ribemont to Bresle. Here we relieved the 11th Battery.

Met Tom Macarron, and had a little pow wow. Plenty of heavies well in evidence, some even forward of where we are. Retired to roost at 2.20 am. Still raining
Entry.198:
Bresle.Bty Position

Weather fine and clear about 7am very heavy clouds filled sky.

At 1.30 pm a Bosche plane attacked an observation ballooon, and brought same down in flames – makes three in two days – not a bad average.

At 5pm left with Mr Parsons and Percy Grayling for F.O.P arrived at 6pm at our destination. Returned to Bty for rations. Arrived at F.O.P. with rations at 10 pm. Fritz shelled lightly till 2pm
Entry.199:
Bresle. F.O.P. and Bty Position.

Weather perfect though a little warm if anything. 

Went on duty from 2 am till 8 am. Very light shelling of Ribemont by the Bosche.

Parson`s arrived on scene demanding water but I made him some tea. About 2 hours later he wanted more tea – he did not get it.

Arrived home at 7pm with Percy. Old Mick Sheedy came up to Battery. Had a heavy thunderstorm in early part of evening drenched everything.

Fritz attack commenced on a 40 mile front
Entry.200:
Bresle. Bty Position

Weather very unsettled and close. Wrote Adey and enclosed two letters. Wrote Ken Gunn and enclosed some letters. Had some very heavy rain during day. Salvaging wire with Tom and prospecting new line. Which we shall endeavour to salvage tomorrow 

Heavy artillery fire somewhere by Viller Brettoneaux, at 9 pm also Fritz S.O.S. signals.

Bosche attack down by Chateau Thierry, official news , on an 88 kilo front.
Entry.201:
Bresle.
