Weather showery, with a fair amount of sun. Tom and myself salvaging about three miles of good metallic. As expected we did not go out of action today. The French made a splendid attack on the Soissons and at 10 pm tonight had captured 20,000 Fritzs. 

I believe they have advanced 10 kilos on a 45 K front. 

Third day made a capture of 400 yds of ground around
Entry.202:
Bresle and Frechencourt.

Weather showery. Reeled in all lines, with Tom Code and after tea left for Waggon Lines. Had journeyed about a kilo when a Staff car pulled up and gave us a flying lift to Pont Noyelles, thus saving a 10 kilo walk, and providing us with an enjoyable ride. Found billet and had a decent feed with Jim Sharp, discussion the latest advance report is 20,000 prisoners and 150 guns
Entry.203:
Frechencourt.

Major asked for volunteers from gunners as spooks and received no reply to his most enticing question. He was slightly disgusted. 

Ran round to Bussey - la Daours and saw friends had a bon spread in honor of my return.

Weather very damp, paid 40 francs and had a little flutter on the cards. Received a new tunic from Q.M. and won a fine example of an Army bycyle.
Entry.204:
Frechencourt.

Weather wet and showery. Rode my bike to Villers Bocage, Rainneville, Cardonette, Coisy and St Gratien. At the last place I ran across Ken Gun and Palmer, at the 5th Divvie Sig School.

Stayed for lunch and had a quiet chat with Ken.

Walked to Behencourt with Smithy and had a nice little snack.

Weather fine, full moon. 

Had some polite visitors during the evening.
Entry.205:
Frechencourt.

Weather fine; received two letters from home, one from E.A. new mail.

Overhauled two miles of D.3. and mended all bares and breaks.

Walked along to a concert with blue and Jim, and enjoyed same immensely.

Watched the Yanks at indoor baseball, and enjoyed the game almost as much as they did.

Weather at night very wet 114th How pulled in late at night.
Entry.206:
Frechencourt.

Weather very wet and miserable, no parades. During the day wrote three letters to folk at home, having had a quiet spell of work.

Inoculation took place . I managed to dodge same.

Walked up to see the concert at the A. Engineers camp but it did not come off unfortunately owing to the rain.

Had a few hours conversation with an American corporal by name Sweeney. th company
Entry.207:
Frechencourt.

Weather showery, rode for a little exercise to Orville via Sarton, Rainches, Toutencourt, Contay, Bavelincourt Behencourt and Frenchencourt.

Met Adrianne at Sarton and had a very exciting afternoon received the usual.

Arrived home at 11pm after a very wet ride. Received a letter from Bully Clement, stating he was due to sail in a weeks time for Australia. answered same but doubt whether he will receive same.
Entry.208:
Frechencourt.

Reeled and overhauled 3 miles of wire. Western, Drew and four others came on to the Spooks job, under compulsion.

Weather showery

Rode 24 kilos a very tiring ride too, but for a very happy reason 

Rode home my 24 kilos after having spent a rather pleasant afternoon.

Weather simply rotten heavy rain and very little did not make the roads too good. Visited McSweeney
Entry.209:
Ribemont. Bty Position

Weather putrid very damp. Received a letter from Roy, also a phot of his highness.

At 3.30 pm orders came to hand to proceed to a 1800 yds behind the line. We were well established in a little trench dugout at 

Met Harry Offer now a W.O. in the 106th Mobile Bdge of Artillery, also Con Tester and Simpson. Had a good old yap.
Entry.210:
Ribemont. Bty Position

Weather wet and miserable throughout the day.

Laid four lines including O.P. which is quite some distance away from our home.

Fritz doing quite a considerable amount of ranging and gunfire during afternoon and night. I think he has pulled some more guns in action up this way. Our trench home completely flooded out during day.

Had a very bombs during the night. 

Mended O.P. wire during the evening.
Entry.211:
Ribemont. Bty Position

Weather still very moist. 

Worked on lines until midnight last night, and until midnight today.

At 2.30pm went out to F.O.O. with Clive Western and mended a couple of breaks en route.

Fritz shelled O.P. with 4.2 H.E. and some fairly nice 5.9s. 

Smithy received some letter from Marguerite and they were answered by myself and himself.

Syncronised time was at 10.20 pm. no idea what time stunt commences.

Smithy recd his photos. Heavies shooting gas.
Entry.212:
Ribemont. Bty Position

At 12.30 am the stunt opened and the barrage went over for 20 minutes then lulled for ten. After 10 minutes it opened again and continued until 20 minutes had passed again. 

At 4.30 am another heavy barrage was laid down for 10 min.

During the stunt Bdge went twice and guns 5 times.

Ran a new piece of line out with Smithy to the O.P. line. Fritz shelling fairly consistently all day. scored a direct hit on the Canal Bank and nearly did some seroous damage.
Entry.213:
Ribemont. Bty Position

At 12.30 am I was awaiting to hear S.O.S. but it did not 

come off. Weather all day muggy and over warm.

Fritz commenced to make things very lively indeed. O.P. wire went in twelve places and Smithy and I mended it. A deuced amount of gas prevalent.

During afternoon line again drifted in three places. Smithy could not come with me unfortunately so I went by myself. Clive spent day at O.P. B.Malcolm and Walker came up from W.L.
Entry.214:
Ribemont. Bty Position

Punctually at 12.30 the line parted company under Fritz barrage. Robbie our best chap was knocked through the shoulder. We spent well over an hour on the lines and eventually fixed them all up. 

Weather very wet and misty spent afternoon on O.P. line. Fritzie having very many duty shoots. 

Out battery got on to a convoy of amm wagons and made them move at the hickory and some Francs. Fritz shelled and bombed the wood up till midnight.

 

August,1918
Entry.215:
Ribemont. Bty Position

Fritz opened up at 12.15 am and tickled up the wood with all breeds of shells up to a 5.9. Battery on duty shoots practically up till 5 am.

Lines went again tonight S.O.S. on the Left sector at 4.3am Travelled O.P. line with telephonist and repaired three good breaks. Walked to test box and fixed up trouble there on Bdge line. At 4.30 pm Fritz raided our balloons and bagged four of the best. A good piece of work. Regt Section goes out tonight. Fritz put barrage down 1st and
Entry.216:
line received materials from O.J.

 

August,1918

Friday 2

Ribemont. Bty Position

At 1 am Fritz again put a heavy general barrage down. I think we shall have a stunt from him shortly. 

No stunt but a heavy front line strafe with Minnies.

Weather fairly moist all day. Right section took over at 9 pm.

Up till midnight nothing had happened at all, save a slight bombardment .

Clive and Johnnie Walker went down to W.L.

 

August,1918
Entry.217:
Ribemont and Lamotte.

Weather wet and miserable. Journeyed over the lines with the fellows taking over, and mended two lines that were down.

Packed up kit and proceeded to W.L. arriving there at 4 am. Had a fairly long walk up to Lamotte.

Battery position at the new place visited by Ammo wagons. Thompson lost his best horse and there were seven horses killed one man wounded Taylor. Weather still wet.

 

August,1918
Entry.218:
Lamotte and Villers Brettoneau.

Arrived at Bty position at 5 am. this morning, wet and fairly tired. Young Ken and Mc settled in a good sort of possie. 

Spent a quiet day, built a little home our original one having been "snowdropped."

Fritz commenced a "mad minute" shoot but did no damage to speak of. Weather wet during the evening Fritz visited district with bombs.

 

August,1918
Entry.219:
Villers Brettoneaux. Bty Position

Arrived at possie at 5 am after a tour of the district. Fritz shelling spasms during the journey up.

At 12 noon orders came to hand to evacuate the trench and Smith and I set to to build a home. Rain settled down at 4 pm and twas still raining at midnight.

Laid O.M. and Gun line . Fritz shelling pretty frequently all day and we had a little gun fire during the night.

 

August,1918

Saturday 24

In Rear of Proyart. Bty Position

Weather dull, but nice and cool. Fritz planes flew fairly low all day.

News from all fronts seems pretty good. Built a nice 

dugout under the road. Received a letter from Uncle Will

– a nice interesting one.

Ken Gun and Red Palmer left for Waggon Lines early in 

the evening. Had trouble with Bdge line and walked it .

Bty pulled out on the main road. Fritz bombing all roads

fairly heavily. Slept in a

dug out near the road.

 

August,1918

Wednesday 7

Villers Brettoneaux. Bty Position

Early during the morning Fritz had a mad minute barrage.

Ken Gunn left with Sheedy for L`aison. Fritz fired a large dump of S.A.A. and big stuff quite handy. He also set a few stretches of camouflage a fire near a gun position. Weather fine and looks like holding for awhile. I hope it does. Best luck to the stunt tomorrow.

 

August,1918
Entry.220:
Villers Brettoneaux. Bty Position

At 4.30 am Fritz commenced a duty shoot with gas and 4.2s also 5.9s. Major Dugan 114th How was killed.

After dinner Fritz settled down a little but shelled spasmodically with a H.V.4.2 gun. I hope to have the pleasure of viewing same one of these near days. 

Fritz bombed us with no detrimental effect during the evening he shelled us fairly constantly. Our guns "duty shooting"all night 

 

August,1918

Friday 9

Bainvillers. Bty Position

Weather fine and clear. Plenty of air fighting. General advance during the afternoon pretty solid work hit easy going as far as fighting was concerned.

15th Bdge did good work also 2nd Bdge 1st Divvie. 

1st Div Art pulled in to a possie alongside of us.

Harbonnier in our hands – at 5 pm.

Spent night in old German dugout evidently a 	Hdqrs, electric light laid on and plenty of foodstuffs.

 

August,1918
Entry.221:
Villers Brettoneaux and 1st Objective.

Weather fair and slightly misty.

Bombardment opened at 4.20 am and we left for an advanced position at 7.20 am

The stunt was well expected and the final objective of the infantry was in their hands at midday. Plenty of work here today. Salvaged some good switchboards and phones. Also a clean shirt.

Fritz downed a couple of our planes but we dropped 6 of his. Some very spectacular sights.

Felt fairly tired at 4.45 pm when we turned in. expect a counter attack tonight.

 

August,1918
Entry.222:
In front of Harboniers, Bty. Pos. 

Weather warm and bright. Battery had a duty shoot at 9 am this morning - preparation for 1st Bdgs attack.

Left with Smithy for the Waggon Lines and picked up a

transportat Bayonville as far as Villers

Brettoneaux and thence lorry to Daours eventually

arriving at Bussy when we had an excellent lunch

consisting of skats and eggs. Returning to our W.L. 

which were fairly close to Home we had a sumptuous 

supper of bread and jam.

Had so few visits from the little Fritz.

 

August,1918
Entry.223:
In Front of Harbonniers. Bty, Pos

Weather fine and clear. Laid an O.P. line with Tom and Ped Palmer 3½ miles in length .

Had a very exciting time doing so and the battery had the pleasure of doing some excellent shooting for the infantry. The 2nd Div were held up by a large garrison of guns and these were eventually cleared. Smithy Tom and myself left for W.L. Battery was to go out of action – but after going half way we returned again on the right of our old possie,
Entry.224:
Div took Lahion. French took Montidier and one or two other small villages.

 

August,1918
Entry.225:
Villers Brettoneaux and Cayeau

Left with column for twas rumoured Rosieres. Ken and myself jumped a motor lorry to Harbonniers, where we waited for column to pass. However column did not come our way so we searched, aided by motor lorries and our feet until we found them situated in a little hollow close to the latter village. The hour was then 11.55.pm so we built our home and before going to sleep listened to the wily Hun dropping his bombs. Heard that old Les Critten was killed from Cpl Andrews. and Spence also Dean were wounded last night

 

August,1918
Entry.226:
Spelling at Villers Brettoneaux

Stayed at a little possie near Hamel for the day. Weather warm. All drivers and gunners went down to Hamel Lagoon and spent the day.

There have been several casualties in the Battery, they are O.B.Walker, Jack Hills (killed) and Bdr Ferguson Jack Gorrick, Bill Hart, Harry Marsh, wounded and Roy Lewis missing.

Got some kit from several sources.

Had a very enjoyable swim in the Lagoon.

Rumor we move up again in the morning.

Had one or two bombs Bdr Townsend wounded

 

August,1918
Entry.227:
Cayeau

Weather very warm and inclined to be very hot.

Received letters from Home. Went up to Bty position for wire and material that we had already carted up on previous days.

Salvaged quite a considerable quantity of wire, very good material too.

Geo Stone`s pass came out for Blighty, he is very lucky indeed. Had a few bombs over, no damage.

 

August,1918
Entry.228:
Cayeau and,

Left for Bty position forward of Rosieres, with a coil of wire, in company of Gunn.

Received a couple of letters of interest from people at home. We returned to Cayeau again at night.

Had word from the
Entry.229:
Casualty Clearing Station that Roy Lewis and Jack Gorrick had died of wounds. He is one of the very best, and I`m very sorry. Had a few visits around the districts but I could find no evidences at hand. Burglar Laurence returned.

 

August,1918
Entry.230:
Morcourt, Bty Post, in front of.

Weather nice for travelling. Left Cayeau at 8.30 am, and proceeded via Wiercourt, Bayonvillers and Eithevanem, to a position outside of Morcourt. 

we relieved the 79th Bdge R.F.A.

En route I met Lance 

Raymond, a very old pal of mine.

Received a package of tobacco from Olive, and Young Francis gave me an Auto Strop razor.

Laid O.P. and O.M. lines.

Have 8 lines in use and Smithy is experimenting with a Fritz phone.

 

August,1918
Entry.231:
Cayeau

Still at this rather pretty place. But somehow after last night I can`t claim to like it very much.

Out salvaging wire all day. Ken Gunn rode across to new Bty position near Morecourt, and he arrived home looking fairly tired.

Made up the old tarphouse again.

Had a few Fritz`s across also a boots enclisers.

Inspected a captured gun

 

August,1918
Entry.232:
In front of Morcourt, Bty Position

Weather dull and a slight drizzle all day. Had a day on lines and stripped a pair of Bosche phones, rebuilding them up again. Albert Garfott came back to the Battery.

112th. Howitzer Battery pulled in right above our dugout, and they have been sending down the dirt into the old Home all day.

Have been very bilious today. Don`t know the cause of the trouble.

 

August,1918
Entry.233:
In front of Morcourt, Bty Position

Weather fine with cool breezes. O.P. line relaid.

Bosche shelled O.P. and Bty the former with 5.9 How and the latter with whizz bangs. – no damage done.

Salvaged a considerable amount of red and material - gave same to Doc Knipe . Returned Line to Bdge

Went at 11.30 p.m. Ken and I fixed her up again.

Fritz phone in action. A very heavy concentration of artillery in this district,

60`s, 9.2?, 8?, 6?, 4.5 and 18s all inside an acre of ground well forward.

 

August,1918
Entry.234:
In front of Morcourt, Bty Pos.

Weather fine and clear. Was informed that Ken Gunn, Smithy, Ped,Tom and myself were recommended for a decoration

About 11.30 Fritz found Bty position with 5.9s and 8 inch howitzers, blew up gun, also Lewis m.g. and wounded Les Alymer "B" sub Catling and Hannermay were also wounded, at forward W.L. Repeated barrage and caught Tommy Pattey in rear. Cut up all our lines. Had a fairly rough day, all through 2 of our guns to 55th – 2 of them knocked out

 

August,1918
Entry.235:
In front of Morcourt, Bty Pos

Weather glorious, fine and clear, plenty of balloons about. Bty did very little shooting 112th shooting all day long.

Walked across to Bdge with Smithy and repaired Q.A. line en route. Purchased supply of canteen stuff, pretty good to the palate.

Received a letter from R. Ladd.

Weather towards evening splendid.

Bty shooting pretty frequently gas shells.

 

August,1918
Entry.236:
1½kilos from Morcourt. Bty. Pos.

The stunt opened up at 4.20 pm. And we were supposed to move forward, but did not do so until early in the evening when we took up a position in the right rear of Proyart.

The weather was very good, nice and warm with a fair breeze.

Up till 5 pm we had captured our objectives and 1900 prisoners.

Laid a line to our new possie from Bdge. Slept under the stars last night.

A few bombs

 

August,1918
Entry.237:
In front of Morcourt, Bty Position

Weather fine and clear.

At 4 am this morning we had a fairly heavy dose of gas, sneezing stuff sent everyone seedy. Fritz cleaned up all our lines again and shelled bty fairly heavily

Weather fine and clear.

At 4 am this morning we had a fairly heavy dose of gas,

sneezing stuff sent everyone seedy. Fritz cleaned up all 

our lines again and shelled Bty fairlyheavily during

morning. Had a day`s solid going on Bdge and Bty lines.

During lunch hour Fritz opened up on 60 pdr Battery

and knocked them about badly. He killed a sgt there, and

jiggered the lines about until they looked like

concertinas. Knipe to L`aison for stunt 

tomorrow. Good luck

 

August,1918
Entry.238:
Between Vane and Hamel. Spell.

Arrived at W.L. early this morning and heard that and Ped Palmer were missing. Ped had been wounded last night with a bomb. I`m afraid that young Ken has been wounded, if so I`m very sorry indeed, for he is one of the very best pals I have ever had.

The weather is very wet at present and I can assure you that our home was fairly moist, never mind. Rained heavily until mid.

 

August,1918
Entry.239:
Hamel to Bty Pos. at 2 kilos ahead of Poyart.

Weather still very showery. 

Left our spelling possie and journeyed via Cevisy and Morcourt and Proyart to a Bty Position selected by the skipper this morning about two kilos ahead of the latter village.

Arrived Bty possie at 9 pm messed about by Makinson who would not allow us to have our pit where we wanted to have it. 

Communication established with Bdge at 10.30 pm. Laid our lines.

No news of Ken Gunn at all. Mac, Walker, Scottie and myself up this time. Tom having a spell.

 

August,1918
Entry.240:
Bty Position ahead of Proyart.

Weather showery. Fritz busy througout the day shelling any and everywhere, three calibres. Walked across to see a 17 inch naval gun captured by 3rd Battalion. A very wonderful large weapon for field work. Evidence shows that it had been blown out by the Bosche, and is now completely destroyed.

My birthday I celebrated very quietly. Went out on Bdge line as far as new German cemetery near Poyart. The Hun shelling every little bit of the district and blew up several graves. The district was gassed very heavily, but we did not get much.

Raining at night fairly heavy.

 

August,1918
Entry.241:
Bty Position ahead of Proyart.

Weather fine and clear, with showers at intervals. We did practically nothing during the mornin. The gunners dad a duty shoot of 100 rounds at 4 am. The enemy has evacuated a considerable amount of property and ground.

At noon we were ordered to move up to an advanced position. We were in action in front of Lappin Wood, which is 3000 yds from the front line or our outposts which have penetrated beyond Heseyvillers and seems to be still going on merrily.

 

August,1918
Entry.242:
Bty Position in front of Lappin Wood.

Weather showery.

Picked blackberries and had a glorious feed, with the addition of a pot of cream. Had a letter from D.W. and Mother.

Received orders at 10 am to move, prepared for same and stood by all day about 11pm orders came saying that we were pulling out about 2am. Tomorrow morning. Played cards and lost a few francs. I had a letter from Ken Gunn, he was wounded by a bomb in Cerisy which fractured his leg.

 

August,1918
Entry.243:
Bourcy . Bty. Position.

Weather cool and wet during early morning. We climbed out at 2.10am and pulled out at 2.20pm.

After 2½ hours on road, we came into position on the slope of a hill behind the above village. We are now back on the Somme battlefield of 1916 again and I can quite believe the stories of the mud that reigned supreme during that winter. 

Smithy and I wired the O.P. 3½ miles kilos, and I reeled the best part up after shooting had finished. Saw our chaps though telescopes walking on the other bank of the canal .

Wrote to Ken Gunn.

 

August,1918
Entry.244:
Bourcy or Barleau Bty Position

Weather fine with a slight drizzle. Fritz shelling roads with 5.9s got the following Battery chaps. Sgt Milner killed, Gunnr Dickson, Voisey, Bdr Spooner, Tommy Main, Drv Hackett. Wounded Anderson, McDonald and Jack Gillam killed. All very fine fellows too. McCartney and young Clive left with Mr Mann for F.O.O. line with Mr Mays and Scottie Malcolm, Relaid wire to same. Turned in at 11.10pm. for a brief rest. 

Stunt to come off in the morning.

Enemy shelling very consistently
Entry.247:
position

3.30 am Awoke to find Mr Mays flashing a torch in my

eyes. Told that the line was down and that I had to 

toddle at the Suites. Went out in the rain to the O.P. Phil 

Thresher wounded in face at 7pm. 

Had a heave of very heavy stuff across, gas galore.

All "D" subs gunners gassed. Richards and Williams

badly gassed.

Orders came through to the effect that we will have to

cross the Somme tonight. I expect twill be a very rough

spin, however good luck.

Peronne captured today by 14th Inf Bdge. 

A very dirty outlook tonight. Left home all clear at 

7.30pm.
Entry.248:
Monday 2

Bty Position close to the Somme

Arrived after an uneventful journey at an old Bty position very close to the river, at 2.15am. 

Slept under the stars until 4.30am when Smithy and I laid a line to 14 A and B HQ. and O.P., a tramp of about 4½ miles in all.

Weather showery .
Entry.249:
Pioneer moved out and we occupied dugouts vacated by them. Established a pit and worked on wire and etc till lunch. Had a shift on the phone until , slept til 5.30pm.

Smithy`s feet pretty bad, bandaged same for him.

"A" battery 298 pulled in close to us.
Entry.250:
Tuesday 3

Bty Position close to the Somme -14th A.1.Bgde.

Weather fine and clear, plenty of work one way and

another.

Salvaging line all day for use in laying to Regt Section.

Laid line to Regt Section and used all the line we

salvaged. Met Jack Harvey in the evening

and spent a very pleasant time. He and his colonel

were the only two officers left in his Batt. The 

casualties have been heavy in taking Mont St.Quentin a

place that Fritz hung on to until the very last.

His right of is the pushing point. Rgt

Section went well forward.
Entry.253:
A.1. Brdge 

Weather fine and clear. Laid a line 5 miles in length to

15th Bdge Hdqrs, where Major and Mr. Kerr were 

observing from.

Naturally felt fairly tired when finished. Received

information to the fact that we were pulling into another

position tonight. Packed up all kits and loaded all

equipment, a pretty long job.

Went across to see Lt John, Battery pulled out to new

position up to and we pulled in 

alongside 51st and 55th Batteries.14th Bgde

received great praise for the capture of Mont St Quentin
Entry.254:
Thursday 5

Attached to 15th A.1. Bdge. Bty position.

Pulled into a position ahead of Birleau to carry on with

sniping work. On road last night we managed to collar 3

miles of metallic wire, a very good find. Salvaged a few

miles of wire with Smithy.

Major returned to Bty position with 3 L`aison spooks, - not in an excellent humor. A heavy thunderstorm came across telephone put a slightly damp home to rest in 

Walked to 5th Div Pioneer Camp and saw numerous fellows I knew. Met Eliza Thoresby and Bill Grant, old Bridg Train fellows. Prepared to leave in the morning.

 

September 1918.

Friday 6

Support 8th A.1. Bdge.Peronne

Evacuated Bty position at 8 pm, and went through Peronne at 11.36 am. Passed main railway and other bridges blown up by Hun in retreat. Passed also railway station which had the devotion of 18 Bdges concentrated fire for 5 minutes.

Halted and had lunch near Peronne also tea. Expected hurry up move. Hurry up move did not come however and "Doc" and myself slept complacently in a nice little dugout near the guns.

News to hand that the Wotan Switch a great Bosche line had been pierced in many parts. Hun still in retreat.
Entry.255:
Saturday 7

Bronne. And a position in Reserve line.

Weather fine and clear during morning, heavy rain in afternoon. Walked across to B.H.Q. and received a nice surprise on having my pay book readjusted.

At 1 pm we took to the road again passing through Cortigny and Le Mesnil towards Beaumetz. Rested and had tea in a gully beneath a very old chateau. Proceeded to the Bty Position and secured a good dug out. In communication at 8.50 pm. With 14th Bdge.
Entry.256:
Sunday 8

In a reserve position, 4 miles from Peronne.

Sunday, a beautiful morning a deadly afternoon.

Had an early visit from Fritz, no material damage so far as I have hard. As we are in reserve we have not been firing and that means a spell for everyone. 

News to hand shews that the infantry advanced on Vendrelles, after capturing Matevillers and Villerscholles. The former village is fairly close to the Hinderburg Line and three miles from St.Quentin.

I wrote a large number of letters.

 

September 1918.

Monday 9

In Reserve position 4 miles from Peronne.

A very heavy downfall of rain from 7am to 11am.

Received a letter from home, also a visit from Fritz 7 planes – no damage.

Had another nice little spell today. Salvaged a little wire, not very much.

Major inspected guns.

Wrote to Doug, Ken Gunn and Cousin Stell.

Had a feed of good quaker oats.

Rumors that the Corps is pulling out very shortly. Hope that is correct.

 

September 1918.

Tuesday 10

In Reserve. 4 miles from Peronne.

Spent a very quiet day, writing letters, Home and abroard.

Weather very miserable all day. Heavy rain made our gully like a drain pipe.

Having quite a spell and now doing nothing else but sleep and eat all day

Mr Mays censored my letters. Rumors of going out very shortly for a little spell, near Amiens.

Read despatch in the London Times.

 

September 1918.

Thursday 12

In Reserve. Hebecourt

Weather very wet and fairly miserable.

Walked across to Frise to see old Yank Watson but had no luck. 

Wrote three letters, and cleaned the telephones. Spent a very quiet night .Met Fisher of 10th A.L. he looks well.

Charlie Adey returned to Bty from school and Blighty leave.
Entry.257:
Friday 13

In Reserve. Hebecourt

Weather showery, inoculated against typhoid fever. Worked during afternoon, Cox leave to Blighty. Paid some money - no good – no canteens.

Played cards and lost a little. Weather wet. 

My spectacular sight during evening about 9 pm. When a Fritz bombing plane was brought down in flames by one of our planes, near our camp. Five Fritzs in searchlights.
Entry.258:
Saturday 14

In Reserve. Hebecourt

Weather showery, and very unpleasant.

News to hand tells old Ped wounded in foot, leg, thigh and shoulder very sorry – one of the best.

A few Fritzs across tonight. 

Overhauled a fair amount of wire.

Rumor going into line again
Entry.259:
Sunday 15

In Reserve. Hebecourt

Weather glorious. A beautiful spring day. Fritz planes across during the morning. Rumor, we are moving again tomorrow.

Played 53rd football – lost.

Heard that Tom Main (wounded at Barleaux) had died of wounds - correct.

Very sorry to hear of this – he was one of the very best. 

Received letter from pal Doug was simply delighted to get it. Seems ages since his previous one arrived. Issue of a chest comforter.
Entry.260:
Monday 16

In Reserve (Hebecourt) and Bouvincourt.

Weather very warm, quite a midsummers day.

Left for line at 10.45 am. and headed to a cluster of bushes near Bouvincourt. Travelled via Braches, Peronne, Doingt and Cartigny to a little position near to the village I mentioned.

Ammo wagons proceeded to Bty position.

About midnight a storm sprang up, and the boys received a very unpleasant drenching.

Smithy and Doc came a beautiful thud.

Wrote D.B.F. and T.L.
Entry.261:
Tuesday 17

Bouvincourt and Bty Position nr. Poeuilly.

Weather, very heavy storm accompanied by the heaviest rain I have seen in France. Had a fair pickle with tarpaulins.

Left with guns for Bty Position at 6.15pm. and arrived in action at 10pm.

Fritz planes across our lines all day.

I have never seen so many Fritzies across at one time

a regular series of showers of bombs. Very few shells and heavy concentration of artillery around the district.
Entry.262:
Wednesday 18

Ahead of Bernes. Bty Position

The stunt is timed of 5.20am. good luck to all the lads.

Weather very wet all day. Barrage opened at 5.25am and there was plenty "hanging" for old Fritz.

At 10am all but one objective was taken.

Grabbed 2635 prisoners and 114 prisoners and advanced in places to a depth of 4000 yds, penetrating the Hindenburg system of outposts.

Moved to a new position near a village, no dugout available.

 

September 1918.

Thursday 19

Rgt of Bernes. Bty Position.

1 am sitting the rain for five hours, drenched to skin, and blankets in a similar condition. All of Br in the same pickle. Moved to a new position i.e. our spooks dugout. 

Weather still about the same . 

Had a letter from Ken Gunn who has had is Rgt leg amputated at the knee and I`m very sorry hear the news.

Nicely settled in new dugout which we have cleaned up. Talbot proceeded on leave and dropped his dixies.

 

September 1918.

Friday 20

Bty Pos.Rgt of Bernes and ahead of Villeret.

Weather wet right through the day. Ordered to new Bty position beneath the wrecked village of Villeret, ahead of the old Green Line.

Made a scratch dugout but during a Fritzer duty shoot, we had a few whiz bangs near the phone.

Fritzer night bomber came down in flames whilst we were on the line.

Spent a very unpleasant night in our makeshift dugout.
Entry.263:
Saturday 21

Ahead of Villeret.Bty Post.

Weather fine for a change. Jim Colbie went on leave to U.K. on a telegram from U.K.

Built a nice little possie splinter proof only.

Whilst on line I picked up a Fritzer revolver.

Sheedy, Waters, Thomson, Steibel and Armstrong left for Aussie leave – very lucky, Believe I will get mine.

Had a lovely time on the lines; Smithy feeling very happy.

Had a heap of bombs in gully.
Entry.264:
Sunday 22

Ahead of La Vigure, Bty Position.

Weather wet, and fairly cool.

Rained very heavily during the afternoon. Fritz very busy all day with shells.

Smithy wrote to Marg mother.

At 9 pm Fritz put down a barrage on the gully. Scottie while sitting alongside me in dugout, stopped one up the forehead. Had a nightmare as the lines which were constantly broken by the barrage.
Entry.265:
Monday 23

Ahead of La Vigure. Bty Position

Weather wet, but getting a little better. Our twin on Bdge O.P. found the crossing to "Line" through barrages, our line became a casualty in many places. Georgie Baker knocked in temple, just a Blighty only.

Have been refused the promised leave to Aussie don`t feel very happy about the matter. Evidently the bosses consider that sole support is not a good enough reason.
Entry.266:
Tuesday 24

Peouilly and La Vigure – Bty Pos.

Weather very showery during the morning, toward afternoon the weather cleared. Relieved by the 231st and returned to W.L. I`ve made a slight mistake we are still in action.

Had another night of liveliness 6 inch How. Bty pulled into position in rear of Bty.

Fritz still barraging ridge and recaptured a little village Palavie.

Great success by Allenby in Palestine. Troops seem to be going well in Salonika
Entry.268:
La Vigure, Bty Pos and W.Line and Peoully

Weather fine and clear. 6 inch How. Registering under Fritz balloon – drew crabs.

Relieved by 231st Bdge, Artillery.

Left old possie and arrived at W.L. about 7.30 pm

 almost caught "F" subs team and crew, also "D" subs.

Spent night with Doc with the old Fritzer bombing about. 

News from Palestine is wonderful. Two Turkish armies cut off. Yanks relieved fourth Bdge. Big stuff coming off very shortly perhaps 29th
Entry.269:
Thursday 26

Waggon Line and Tincourt

Weather glorious fine and clear. Spent morning cleaning up phones and overhauling wire. Have every reason to believe that we shall be in action tonight.

Packed up kit and left with wagons for new W.L. near Tincourt, by the railway line. Seems quite civilised to hear the trains again. Arrive new W.L. at 9.30 pm and rigged up a tarpaulin for the night.

Rained during the evening not very hard, Met Mosely and Don Cooker also Gus Knox.\
Entry.270:
Friday 27

Tincourt and we are still here.

Weather wet during the morning, having a farily busy time with wire and etc.spent a fair amount of time on different work.

Georgie Baker returned from hospital

Am inclined to believe that the big stunt comes off on Sunday morning, but could not say with any reliability

Met Les Fuller, and one or two other boys.

Spent a good night under the new blankets and dugouts.
Entry.271:
Saturday 28

Tincourt. Spell

Weather very damp and close. Terry Smith and Percy Grayling promoted to Bdr. I was very pleased to hear the latter news.

Bulgaria seems to be in a pitiful pickle and "Jacko" is having a fairly warm time. Having a fairly busy time. 

Went to Don for lamp and pliers – got both.

Stunt to come off in the morning. We are going across with the second wave. I understand Reveille is to at 1 am tomorrow. Best of luck for the stunt. Tom Code and McCully to L`aison
Entry.273:
Advanced to position in rear of Hargicourt. Weather very soggy. Reveille at 1 am. Left for position in rear of Bellinglisk at 3am. Barrage opened at 5.15 am. Yanks took their first objective by 11 oclock. They were slightly disorganised by fog and m.g. fire.

We landed into a very rough possie, and have so far been fortunate enough to only have two casualties. Mr Kerr and driver Hutchinson – both Blightys.

Laid a line through a m.g. barrage and 5.9, 4.2, ditto but find I could not maintain same owing to the dirty wether. Slept in a shell hole for the night.
Entry.275:
In rear of Hargicourt, or Bellicourt. Weather fine; at 6.0 am our lads went across and captured their objectives, that could not be taken yesterday owing to insufficient art support,

Had a further nightime from midnight to 4am. Heavy frost overnight, and a more than cold breeze which penetrated to the marrow. Had two trips on the forward line. Tom Code had been hemmed in by m.g. fire. Made our quarters in an old Fritz dugout past the Hindenburg Line. 

On two occasions today our guns were firing at 2800 with 71°L 53°L on.- rather risky
Entry.276:
Tuesday 1

In rear of Hargicourt (advanced to rgt. of Bellicourt)

Weather fine and clear had a little trouble with lines and did 5 to 8 am shift.

French service time came into force today.

Battery moved forward to right flank of Bellicourt, came through village at the "tuite".

Established in a pill box, but Peter objected so I suppose we shall have to move.

Had the 10 to midnight. Feel very tired "sissoir". Fritz shelling pretty regularly.
Entry.277:
Wednesday 2

On right of Bellicourt behind Nooroy.

Weather warm and fine. Walked over and repaired Bdge Line, Fritz particularly busy shelling Bellicourt village. Cavalry came back from Le Catelet, not having done too good owing to the amount of wire and m.g. nests, yet to be cleared by tanks.

Visited the St Quentin Canal and viewed the supposed boiling down chamber used by the Bosche to extract the fats of the human body. Personally I consider the place has been a cook house or something of the kind. A fair number of tanks and armoured cars going up.
Entry.278:
Thursday 3

On right of Bellicourt, Bty Position.

Weather fine and warm

I feel very sad today for one of my very best pals Smithie has left for Australia. Several other fellows in this Battery have all gone to Australia today.

An attack this morning resulted in the capture of Ramicourt with over 3000 prisoners.

Packed up to move out for a spell today, but did not go. We are to go into action for a stunt on 5th tomorrow morning, as this mornings work has left us out of range. Believe we are to go in the line again tomorrow.
Entry.279:
Friday 4

On right of Bellicourt, and rear of Johncourt

Weather very moist. Wagon lines came up this morning. Issued with a new pair of boots. – bad pair, wrote to O.J. a letter that altho phrasing was severe, was essential. At 3.45 pm we went into action again behind and to the left of Johncourt. Dug a bivvie into the side of the railway bank. Evidently there is to be a stunt of some size around here shortly, in the morning perhaps .

One of Fritzs barragers caught a team and waggon and did no end of damage. A great number of Scottish dead in this railway cutting.
Entry.280:
Saturday 5

In read of Johncourt. Bty Position.

Stunt opened at 5/15 am, advance of 1500 yds. 2nd Div pioneers hopped the bags captured a few hundred prisoners. 

A wild rumor started to the effect that we are going out of action for a spell. As usual turned out to be that we are not going out but going up farther forward to a new position near Ramicourt.

After all we did not move today either forward or back. Jocks have been burying their dead all day.
Entry.281:
Sunday 6

In rear of Joncourt. On left Ramicourt.

Day broke fine and clear.

A great deal of bombing by Fritz planes who have held the air all day. 

Went forward with Clive to Bty position on the outskirts of Ramicourt. Grabbed a fairly decent dugout for Spooks pit. And built her up a little with some frontal protection. 55th had no dugouts so their spooks can pad with us. Only Tom Code ,Charlie Adey and myself left up here. Stunt rumored to be dwelling .

Yanks relieved Tommies.
Entry.282:
Monday 7

In rear of Ramicourt, Bty Pos.

Weather decidedly unsettled these days and there are

rumors of a further stunt in the morning.

Fritz very busy shelling the above villages and barraging a great deal of stuff in the valley.

Warned for hop over in the morning, with the Yanks. Have to carry 24 hours rations. Had an excellent feed in the village or rather what came from the village.

Got a good clean change too. Have left all my gear with Tom. Good luck to stunt in the morning.
Entry.283:
Tuesday 8

With the 3rd Bttn Hdqrs.

Joined up the above crowd of Yanks last night.

Moved from Hdqs Ramicourt to a new one in Monteberain. Ran into Fritz barrage in the above village.

At 5.10 am our barrage crashed out, I got caught again in barrage.

Weather held good throughout. Proceeded to Brancourt and established a new hdqrs there. Had a hell of time, one never to be forgotten. Ran rations and wounded for some time, very sad scene in a house in this village.

 

October 1918.

Wednesday 9

With the 3rd Batt Hdqrs (115) and 2nd Batt 120.

Weather foggy, spent a wild night with bombs, advanced with the infantry to the railway line Nth of Behein, near the railway line, reported with Page and Cooper to the
Entry.284:
Batt 120 Regt. – Major Grahame.

After the infantry had advanced 500 yds Hdqrs was established in a farm house.

I went back with a despatch and after a 3 hours wait got through to Capt Leneham at Regt Hdqrs. Answered in the negative. Set off again to the Line but at 12 midnight was still lost, so I turned in at an old cottage for the night. Bitterly cold
Entry.285:
Thursday 10

With 2nd Batt,120. Regt Hdqrs

Left for the line at 4.30 am and have been hunting for my officer since then. Country about here very pretty. Met Mr Cooper at 5.15 am just in time to do the hop over with he and Page. Page had a mg bullet through his rifle. The going has been pretty tough and we consolicated a few hours later, the first objective near Vaux Vigney – Two Batt of Yanks coming to our relief were badly knocked about by artillery and mg fire. A very rough day.
Entry.286:
Friday 11

With 2nd Batt 120 Regt. Vaux Vigney.

Spent a putrid night and had a pretty rotten spin in a little skeleton trench. Fritz being busy all night with mg and whiz bangs. Hopped the bags once again at 4.58 am with a very weak barrage. Got the first objective where we were relieved by a L`aison party from 11th Bdge. Walked to Bahain and travelled from there in a staff car to the outskirts of Ramicourt, where we found our batteries in reserve. Slept all day the sleep that I`m sure I have well earned.
Entry.287:
Saturday 12

In reserve, Ramicourt

Weather wet. Tommy burial party very busy getting the dead buried. Trumpeters played the Last Post over 200 buried. Received a few letters, very welcome too. Had a shot with Jim`s revolver. Had a good rest all day.
Entry.288:
Sunday 13

Ramicourt and in front of Busigny (Bty Pos)

Weather wet throughout the day. Left for a Bty position, and travelled via Montrebrain,Ponchaux, Maretz, and Busigny. 

Whole bdge camped together."Doc" stayed at Waggon Lines, very sorry he did so "Shunner" now Sgt Major – worse luck.

Fritz shelling village all night, Bishop, Mc Caffery, O.B.Walker, and several other old chaps all back again. Connected with Bdge, early in the day and fixed up nicely by midnight. Made a turn through Maretz. 

Mc and Roussell at guns.
Entry.289:
Monday 14

Ahead of Busigny. Bty Position.

Weather wet and very chilly all day. Played cards and then laid a mile line to O.P. Went across to village near by and procured some fine vegetables, beans, turnips, carrots, potatoes and cabbage. Had an excellent tea, the above vegs and roast beef.

Word came through that the Hun had evacuated, no truth in the rumor.

Received some fine letters from cousins and Aunt Isa.

Feeling fairly tired. Had a few shells across.
Entry.290:
Tuesday 15

Ahead of Busigny Bty Position

Weather wet and showery all day. Bty did a few small duty shoots. Tom and myself went forward to dig a position for our advanced pit. Had a fairly easy day considering the circumstances.

Had a nice long shift 12 to 4 this morning . expect to be moving up very shortly to a position 800 yds behind the line. One section is to, I believe go forward.
Entry.291:
Wednesday 16

Bty position and advance ditto.

Wet wet all day. Cooked for boys, captured a few rabbits. Had a little shooting with my automatic Fritzer – pretty accurate. 

Laid out l. of fire and two O.M. lines, also Bdge, Must have walked kilos. Fritz put a 4.2 on the dugout wall. Not feeling very well. Had a little gas.

At 18.30 Bty moved forward to a forward position near the line, don`t like the line of dugouts. Stunt comes off in the morning – Good luck.
Entry.292:
Thursday 17

Advance position and in front Becvigny.

Heavy fog and rain heralded the stunt this morning. Barrage very heavy, laid down on Fritz line. Poor headway made by the Tommies against Fritz, and we left their flank crossing to the Yanks 120th Regt in the line again and as usual held up. They are very poor fighters and seem to have very poor leaders.

Heavy rain all the day, and that made things very uncomfortable. News to hand that Roy`s application for my leave has come through, same has been recommended by the Major.
Entry.293:
Friday 18

With the forward Section, Forward Position.

Barrage opened at 5.35 am, Left battery 0600, and stopped outside Molain with the forward Section. Laid a line to F.O.O. but all the work was for nothing as the Yanks did not take the advantage of the barrage, much to my disgust. Returned to our Bty at 1750 which had moved across to St Martin.

Spent an eventful evening received a little mail which was very welcome and included a letter from E.A.

Fritz did not do much shelling.

 

October 1918.

Saturday 19

Bty Pos. left of Ribeaville

Weather wet. Packed up kit and left Bty at 0600. Advanced to a position in the above village but was shelled out of same during the afternoon.

Picked up a fresh possie pretty rough too. Laid a line 1./2 long to Bttn Headqrs, and have had a hell whilst maintaining it. Fritz barrages everywhere and has had a few wins today.

Weather wet right through, dug another dugout and am absolutely done up. – dead beat.

 

October 1918.

Sunday 20

left of Ribeaville. Bty Pos.

3 am Fritz put down a barrage of gas and H.E. very constant and close too. Knocked the runners mule. Walid came along and called out that he was off to Blighty. Major and Gill swimming about 4 am. Peter Redmond ,made a Major.

Busy salvaging wire all day long, very heavy work lately and an tired out. So is old Tom Code. Pulled in about two miles raining all the while and I`m feeling just about done in.

 

October 1918.

Monday 21

Rear of Mazingheim. Adv.Pos.

Had a pretty rough night last night. On shift 5.8. Felt fever coming on about midnight. Left to collect my Blighty pass. Saw M.O. Don`t remember anything else until the 23rd.
Entry.294:
Tuesday 22

Evidently en route to Base Hospital

 

October 1918.

Wednesday 23

Don`t know where. On a train. Know I am plenty others are. Head aching badly. Feel rotten

Arrived same hospital as Ken Gunn and Teddie Dunn are in. put in bed alongside of Teddie Dunn in lucks way.

 

October 1918.

Thursday 24

12th St Louis, Hos. Rouen

Well I feel a little better this morning but gee whiz I had a pretty rough spin these last few days.

I can remember fleeting glimpses of scenery and then folk but nothing else. Fine doc here only a youngster but for all that he is very good.

 

October 1918.

Friday 25

12th St. Louis Hosp. Rouen

No recollections owing to a relapse
Entry.295:
Saturday 26

On board S.S. Panama.

Had a fairly sever relapse yesterday. Woke this morning to find myself on a hospital ship on our way across the channel. 

Left at 8pm for Sthampton.
Entry.297:
1st Sthten. Stirchley Sec. Birmingham.

After an long tedious trip awoke to find myself in the above hospital surrounded by Aus, Yanks and Kanucks.

Feel a little better. Sent off four wires to different places. Wired Roy maybe he will come up here.
Entry.299:
Hosp. Birmingham

Temp 100º not feeling too bad.

Made a study of my surroundings and fellow patients.

Wrote one or two letters.
Entry.301:
Hosp. Birmingham

War news pretty good today.

Heavy rain all day.

Have come to the conclusion that of all the day sisters and nurses there is no one to touch Sister Barron for a thorough sport. Petite.

Bought a bon little watch from the yank.
Entry.303:
Hosptl. Birmingham

Last night the Yank and Pedderson were taken to the tents. Inspection by some long streak of a Capt. Played Brad draughts and cards all day. Have come to the final conclusion that the biggest wag and best sport on night duty is Nurse Macdonald – an Irish nurse.
Entry.305:
Hosptl. Birmingham

Weather wet. Brad arose today for the second time .

Hostilities between Turkey and the allies ceased at noon today. The official news has not yet been published.
Entry.306:
Friday 1

Hosptl. Birmingham

Official news today declares the unconditional surrender of Turkey.

Austria may collapse at any time now, and then perhaps a month will see the v.e.

The food in this place is rather poor considering that it is a hospital.
Entry.307:
Saturday 2

Hosptl. Birmingham

I`ve certainty had a very pleasant surpise today. My beloved brother paid me a visit and I was ever so pleased to see his smiling face again. He is going to get me to Southall and that place will do me. I know Mac, Preston and Milliard also Barron are four names that I want to remember. Roy left for London this afternoon.
Entry.308:
Sunday 3

Hosptl. Birmingham

The weather today is the limit. There has been a heavy Scotch mist all day making the place simply miserable. Had one letter only, from London. Am waiting for news of my approved transfer to the same hospital as Roy is a patient of.

Hungary has signed an armistice.
Entry.309:
Monday 4

Hosptl. Birmingham

Good news again today. Austria has signed an armistice, the terms of which are not published. Had the pleasure of spending all day out of bed, but feel pretty seedy tonight.

Grub improved just a little in quantity.

Weather wet and miserable. 

Received au petite correspondence pour la jeune fille, Simonnè au Busey-la-Dours – oui, bon neuvelle pour le guerre
Entry.310:
Tuesday 5

Hosptl. Birmingham

300 to 50, with Da Costa settling day today. So I`ve won my bet eh! Well that is not so bad altho I thought I`d surely lose it. 

Weather brilliant. Letter from ).J. very pleased to receive same.
Entry.311:
Wednesday 6

Hosptl. Birmingham

Weather wet, no fresh developments in Germany
Entry.312:
Thursday 7

Hosptl. Birmingham

Wired Roy the results of Dr`s markings. Name
Entry.313:
Friday 8

Hosptl. Birmingham

No answer yet from Roy.

Weather wet and pretty miserable.

Marked for walks.

Germany asking for armistice. And is sending 2 admirals and two generals to meet Fock.
Entry.314:
Saturday 9

Hosptl. Birmingham

No fresh terms for Peace.

The courier despatched by Germany had been held up.

Went up to Birmingham with Johnson.
Entry.315:
Sunday 10

Hosptl. Birmingham

Kaiser abdicated and Crown Prince relinquished all claims to the throne.

Peace declaration is expected at any time now.

Went to Birmingham with Johnson had an O.K. time yesterday and today.
Entry.316:
Monday 11

Hosptl. Birmingham

Weather fine and clear, went into town with Johnson. 

News of armistice having been signed by the Hun arrived at this place at 10.15pm. the wildest scenes of excitement in town, everyone went mad. There were some very pretty sights. 

Leave extended to 8 pm and we had a few nice btts of Bubbly to celebrate the occasion.

Tis a very hard job to describe my emotions at the news, and I think that twould be a hard thing for anyone to do so.
Entry.317:
Tuesday 12

Hosptl. Birmingham

Weather fine and clear. Spent quite a happy time up town, amongst the crowds. Could not get anything stronger than sugarless tea to drink

Arrived home a little late. Brad went out to the tents, and Les pretty disappointed judging by his outward appearance.

Spent a nice quiet afternoon and evening at Sutton Coldfields with – Managed to get some Barribals and Kirchners.
Entry.318:
Wednesday 13

Hosptl. Birmingham

Weather perfect – similar to our dear homeland in mid winter.

Had the pleasure of L-s company around down and enjoyed the afternoon thoroughly .

Had a peep at the Cinema and afternoon tea at the Oak Rooms.

Returned to time.

Sgts marked to Convalescents.

A. Hospital 

Brad left for some Hall.
Entry.319:
Thursday 14

Hosptl. Birmingham

Weather wet and fairly miserable. Went up town nothing doing there. Came home to a whist drive and scored only 136 points out of 20 games. 

Had a letter from Roy first since he left.
Entry.320:
Friday 15

Hospital. Birmingham

Weather fine and clear and a happy afternoon was spent at Sutton Coldfield with -

Had a very fine afternoon in town playing billiards. Went to a picture theatre with Sgt Gott and enjoyed myself immensely.
Entry.321:
Saturday 16

Hospital. Birmingham

Weather fine and frosty

Wired Roy for further particulars of transfer.

Heard a wild rumor to the effect that 3rd Divvie was being demobilised.

Went to Kings Heath village with N.

Spent a good time up town with Sgt Gott.
Entry.322:
Sunday 17

Hospital. Birmingham

Weather wet but not too bad. Accompanied by Sgt we strolled to a recital by an orchestral society. The turn out was excellent.

Had afternoon tea at the , only a small affair .

Scaled wall and found a nice French Bed and pajamas all ready for me.

Sister P. helped me to straighten out the muddle like a thorough sport.
Entry.323:
Monday 18

Hospital. Birmingham

Weather fine and clear.

Went up town with Sgt and had a look in at photoplay. 

Had afternoon tea performed several shopping manouvres not feeling too bright.

That evening in bed and had a slight increase in temperature.

 

November 1918.

Tuesday 19

Hospital - Birmingham and Southall

Left hospital at 11.30am and caught the 12.10 back to London arriving at S.thall eventually at 7.30

Met Roy and was placed into the same ward as he, much to my pleasure. As I did not feel too well, I went to bed.
Entry.324:
Wednesday 20

Hosptl. Sthall

Afta examination by Capt Pigott, I made a tour of workshops and hosptl surroundings with Roy.

Ran out to see Eve and stayed all night with a Mr Harris – some friend of Roys.

I am agreeably surprised to see agile manner in which Roy gets about despite his physical incapacity.
Entry.325:
Thursday 21

Southall. Hospital

Weather wet and miserable. Spent day at workshops on little jobs. Made a nice lighter.

Met a parcel of letters and papers from home.

Ran across to Wembley and saw O.J. surprising her very much. Roy accompanied me much to Mrs Jones pleasure. Olive look very queer and thin and I`m sure
Entry.326:
Friday 22

Southall. 

Spent the day in a very quiet manner indeed. Had a slight recurrence of fever again.

Went before final board and received news of the fact that I was on the boat roll
Entry.327:
Saturday 23

Southall. Hospital

Spent a rather quiet morning. Did not go to the workshops as they were closed all day.

Went across to O.s in the afternoon and stayed until I missed the last train from Wembley, thus missing the last from Paddington also. Had to walk to Ealing and a bus – militaire carried me almost the remaining portion of the journey. Felt pretty dicky too.
Entry.328:
Sunday 24

Hospital. Southall

All day in bed, at 6.30 pm, I dressed and went out with Roy to Eve`s at Peckham.

Spent a very quiet evening there and returned early
Entry.329:
Monday 25

Southall. Hospital

Feeling fairly rotten today and am looking forward to a good furlough, commencing tomorrow morning.

Temp 101º at 6 am - 103º 6 pm. Settled down to a Turkish bath and felt much better at midnight.
Entry.330:
Tuesday 26

Hospital and Wembley

Left hospital at 10 am and spent a very quiet time at Hsferry Road.

Arrived at Wembley in due course. Met O on the platform

Had a very pleasant evening – a musical one with Vic and a few others.

Had lunch with Bert in town. Received a letter of some character from D.B.F.
Entry.331:
Wednesday 27

Wembley. On furlough

Spent a very pleasant day up town, avec chere Vic and O.

Wired to Smithy to come on down

Weather wet and miserable.

Met quite a number of O`s pals at the office.

Had a very nice musical evening in honor of Vics departure of France tomorrow.

In bed at 3 am tomorrow.
Entry.332:
Thursday 28

Wembley . On furlough

Went up on early train with Mr.Jones and Vic to Victoria.

Met "O" at 1 pm on Marlebone Station and received smithy`s wire.

Met Smithy at 2.25 pm at Kings Cross.

Went down to Baker St and met Margeurite Vaugnat also Miss Westport.

Made arrangements for tomorrow. Left cakes in the carriage.
Entry.333:
Friday 29

Wembley. On Furlough

Went up to town at 11am. Met Smithy and Percy Grayling in the Aldwych Y.M.

Went out to Lyons for lunch and then booked seats for "You never know Yknow" at the Criterion Theatre.

Made up a neat little party and had a very enjoyable evening.

Expect to leave tomorrow for Bristol to see Ken Gunn.
Entry.335:
Wembley. Bristol and Wembley

Oh! What a life.

Travelled up town caught 12.7 pm for Bristol, returned after a wild goose chase, to Wembley, per District tram and boot.

Arrived home at 1 am quite a respectable hour, and felt absolutely exhausted.

After such a tiring day. Wondering whether old Smithy got a bad. I hope he did.
Entry.337:
Wembley. On furlough. Slept until noon. Had a glorious hot tub, and spent a pleasant afternoon.

Went to Church and held hands after service.

Mrs Jones is picking up very rapidly indeed and I sincerely hope she will soon be her old self.

Made arrangements to take Eve to theatre on Tuesday night. Cnr of Oxford St and Ttham Ct Road at 6.30 pm. 

Wrote E and Mother, also old "Doc" Sharpe.

Made arrangements for a party on Wed next also.
Entry.339:
Wembley. On furlough

Went up town with Olive and ran down through Harrods guided by Vi and Florrie. Purchased a few articles and had tea.

Travelled home via Marlebone.
Entry.341:
Wembley On furlough.

Received a letter from Smithy, so he did not go to Ireland.Gives Leeds a good name.

Weather wet. Went to Palladium with Charlie, Vic and Olive. Splendid show too. Visited Cooks and made inquiries for sailing.

Weather still wet at midnight, I wonder does it ever cease to rain.
Entry.343:
Wembley On furlough.

Received a wire from Smithie to meet him at Y.M. at 11 am tomorrow. Wired to Birmingham instructions.

Spent quiet evening at home visiting Mr Harrison near by.
Entry.345:
Wembley On furlough.

Went up town to meet Smithie but arrived late and 

was of course disappointed. Ran home to see 

percy`s friend and missed them there. Ran out to

Mrs Rainers with Olive Very decent people they

seem

Arrived home and got in A1

Heard that D25 and D26 sail on
Entry.347:
Saturday 7

Wembley On furlough.

Weather attempted to be bright but failed after the initial attempt. Went shopping with all the people here and came back "comme cent pottiereie."

Perhaps we shall have some fine weather.

 

December 1918.

Sunday 8

Wembley On furlough.

Mrs Rainer came across to see Olive and she stayed all day. 

I certainly think considerably of Mrs. R.

Roy wrote a rather sarcastic implicating letter and I answered it with one in a similar tone.

Dear O. is so very tired and she seems to be becoming very queer.

 

December 1918.

Monday 9

Wembley and Birmingham

Weather wet. Ran up to Brum early morning train. Came back and received a pair of wires, one granting extension the other from Roy, another example of silly sarcasm.

Had a letter from P.G. written from B- I`m very sorry to receive the news . Spent a few happy hours with O. during the evening. Ran down to Harrow for an hour or so bought some presents for Roy`s wife.

 

December 1918.

Thursday 12

Wembley and Southall.

Left home early and reported back to Hospital after meeting Roy and Eve up town. Went with Eve to the Prince of Wales, and saw Fair and Warmer. Not a bad style of show, but very little music at all.

Today I have been through several examinations and inspections. Boat leaves tomorrow. 

The " The Naughty Wife" with Eve and O et Roy.
Entry.348:
Friday 13

Southall and H.S.S. "Karoola"

Weather as usual – dull and miserable. Handed in kit and wrote a few letters. Received an answer pre paid cable from Elsie. I was certainly very pleased to receive same. 

Entrained and left S`thall at 1.30pm.Went aboard and was allotted a cot up at the fos`cle head of the old "Karoola".

Quite a large number of patients aboard.

Left the berth and anchored in mastream off battery.
Entry.349:
Saturday 14

At Sea. H.S."Karoola."

Weather very moist and a slight sell running. A great number of the lads aboard feeling very seasick and looking it.

The food is excellent in quantity and quality. Had a game of Loto. Purchased some stores for the trip.

Left Sthampton roads at 11.30pm. last night and proceeded down stream

We are fast entering the Bay of Biscay. – 7.50 pm.

Wrote to D.B.F.
Entry.350:
Sunday 15

At Sea. H.S."Karoola."

Weather unsettled, wet and fine – fairly heavy seas. Shipped a few .

Plenty of chaps very sick.- so far no sickness.

Beautiful food aboard as the example menus show.

Breakfast ,porridge, sugar and milk, steak bacon and potatoes. Dinner. Boiled beef turnips potatoes and plum duff, soup. Tea. Bread and butter, jam, tomato sauce and cold beef etc. with cold potatoes.

Had made a run of 299 miles in the 24 hours from 

noon yesterday.

George still seasick.
Entry.351:
Monday 16

At Sea. H.S."Karoola."

Weather fine and clear.

Nice smooth sea and a few newcomers are noticeable on deck.

Up till non today we had steamed another 326 miles for 24 hours.

Played poker and lost £1. Passed five ships going northl.

We are at present off the coast of Spain and should reach Gibraltar by 5 pm tomorrow.

George better today.
Entry.352:
Tuesday 17

At Sea. H.S."Karoola."

Weather fine and clear averaged 14.2 miles and for 24 hours had travelled 335 miles.

Played Auction Bridge and one.

Met Bill Hart and Don Cameron.

Passed through the Straights of Gibraltar at 8 pm.

The town and rock were a blaze of light as also was Algiers.

Wrote to Ken Gunn. Climbed up to the yard arm of the mainmast.
Entry.353:
Wednesday 18

At Sea. H.S."Karoola."

Weather fine and splendid sailing sea – like a mill pond.

Played Auction and commenced my entry for the best trench yarn. Travelled for the 24 hours 324 miles making a total mileage of 1408 miles.

With the sea as it is I think we should be at Malta or rather Port Said on the 23rd.

 

December 1918.

Thursday 19

At Sea. H.S."Karoola."

Weather fine and warm. Saw a most beautiful moonlight scene and a magnificent sunset today.

The old "hooker" is busy grinding out her 15 miles per hour and had travelled another 345 miles since last night.

The sea today is helping her along a great deal, and she has the benefit of a nice 4 knot breeze.

Play Auction Bridge discussed Egypt and wrote letters. Stores still holding good.

 

December 1918.

Friday 20

At Sea. H.S."Karoola."

Weather very wet but brighter in the afternoon.

Commenced a long letter home which I`m hoping will arrive before I do.

"She" did her 347 miles today which means that we have now 1092 miles to go before we reach Port Said.

I suppose we shall have Xmas Day in or not far from Suez. Played Auction until I felt too bad to do so. Had a relapse of fever which I quite expected.
Entry.354:
Saturday 21

At Sea. H.S."Karoola."

Weather fine and clear. Ship still keeps her speed pretty well. 345 miles is the distance travelled during the last 24 hours.

Having a pretty good time. Wrote p.c. to Smithie, Percy G, Tom Code, Jim Sharp, Marg, Olive, Miss Brent, Eve, Mr Broone, Ken Gunn, Nurse Mac and Nurse Lottie, posted them all today.
Entry.355:
Sunday 22

At Sea. H.S."Karoola."

Went to church service, ship rolled a considerable amount in doing her 325 miles. We have still a matter of 437 miles to go .

Weather becoming warmer and there was a very fine sun shining yesterday.

Lost £2 again after a game of nap.

 

December 1918.

Monday 23

At Sea. H.S."Karoola."

Weather wet and drizzly with very heavy rain at intervals. At lunch time we had a little matter of 104 miles to do before the port closed for the night. Our trip today was 327 miles.

At 8.30 pm we were still outside Port Said perhaps tomorrow we shall be inside when we awake.

 

December 1918.

Tuesday 24

At Sea. and Port Said."Karoola"

Weather unsettled and inclined to be very cool. After turning around all night, and we entered the port at 7.30 am 

Purchased a few articles and despatched three post cards to England. The boys had quite a good team in the purchasing of goods from the bumboat kings.

I had quite a job as interpreter and caught quite a deal of things for nothing. 

R.M.S. Mandala passed out. Two wrecks just outside.
Entry.356:
Wednesday 25

Port Said. H.S."Karoola."

Weather fairly decent. Berthed and coaling still. Had a fine xmas dinner, pork and Duck with plum duff to follow. For tea we had salmon, green peas, potatoes with jelly and tinned peaches.

Left Port Said at 6.30 pm. Passed Kantara at 9.55 and Fedan at 11pm. Passed Ismailia at 11.30
Entry.357:
Thursday 26

Suez Canal, Suez, Red Sea."Karoola"

Passed all the old spots, Gereffe, Shallufa, Kubri, and Gurkha and Baluchistan Posts. Weather ideal a nice cool breeze.

Passed the old "Daphne". Had a yarn with Harry Rich who is on board. Left Suez at 1.35pm and commenced our run down to Colombo where we expect to arrive on or about the 10th.

 

December 1918.

Friday 27

At Sea. Red Sea. "Karoola."

Weather warming up slightly, and the sea has been like glass. Roy has been appointed Secretary to the Sports Committee.

Travelled 254 miles from Suez, and 90 miles through the canal.

Played cribbage and lost. Played Auction bridge for a little while.

Issued with a clean change and handed in my contribution to the "Karoolian`s " Editor.
Entry.359:
At Sea. Red Sea. "Karoola."

Weather very hot, but tempered a little by a fair breeze from the Sth East.

Played cribagge all day and read a book of Stevenson`s poems. Travelled 27 miles for the 24 hours trip . issued with tobacco and chocolate, very decent too.
Entry.361:
At Sea. Red Sea. "Karoola."

Weather very warm with a nice cool breeze from the beam. Orders issued allowing Sisters to sleep on the Port Side and officers to sleep on the starboard side of the boat deck. Caused a fair amount of comment. Running into a solid ground swell. Issued with shorts. Wrote a copy of "Sounds of night" for the Karoolian" wrote to Bunty. Splendid dinner today.
Entry.363:
At Sea. Red Sea. Indian Ocean.

Weather warmer by a great deal, and the climate is beginning to swelter along a fair amount. Ran into a heavy ground swell.

Passed the twelve apostles early in the afternoon. Played in the Bridge Tournament and lost in the first round by 28 points. Played cribbage for about three hours and lost 2/6 on the deal.

Days run very poor. 254 miles only.
Entry.365:
At Sea. Indian Ocean. "Karoola."

Weather fair not quite so warm today. Passed at 8 am. Commenced the second round of the Tournament. One of our members died a chap named Private from W.A. he was buried at "Lights out." There was no actual attendance of the patients. Hard luck for his people.

Had a nice iced glass of beer to wish the New Year in. Awoke at midnight to hear a Scotchman playing the pipes. Passed Aden at 10.30 pm. Travelled 251 miles only
